G.f.: 1/(1-x/(1-2*x/(1-2*x/(1-4*x/(1-3*x/(1-6*x/(1-4*x/(1-8*x/(1-5*x/(1-10*x/(1-6*x/(1-... (continued fraction); coefficients of continued fraction are given by floor((n+2)/2)*(3-(-1)^n)/2 (A029578(n+2)). - _Paul Barry_, Mar 30 2010
G.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} n!*x^n / Product_{k=1..n} (1-k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jul 20 2011
a(n) = A074206(q_1*q_2*...*q_n), where {q_i} are distinct primes. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Aug 05 2011

The adjusted e.g.f. A(x) := 1/(2-exp(x))-1, has inverse function A(x)^-1 = Integral_{t=0..x} 1/((1+t)*(1+2*t)). Applying [Dominici, Theorem 4.1] to invert the integral yields a formula for a(n): Let f(x) = (1+x)*(1+2*x). Let D be the operator f(x)*d/dx. Then a(n) = D^(n-1)(f(x)) evaluated at x = 0. Compare with A050351. - _Peter Bala_, Aug 31 2011
a(n) = D^n*(1/(1-x)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator (1+x)*d/dx. Cf. A052801. - _Peter Bala_, Nov 25 2011
E.g.f.: 1 + x/(G(0)-2*x) where G(k) = x + k + 1 - x*(k+1)/G(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 11 2012

E.g.f. (2 - 2*x)*(1 - 2*x^3/(8*x^2 - 4*x + (x^2 - 4*x + 2)*G(0)))/(x^2 - 4*x + 2) where G(k) = k^2 + k*(x+4) + 2*x + 3 - x*(k+1)*(k+3)^2 /G(k+1) ; (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 01 2012
G.f.: 1 + x/G(0) where G(k) = 1 - 3*x*(k+1) - 2*x^2*(k+1)*(k+2)/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 11 2013.
G.f.: 1/G(0) where G(k) = 1 - x*(k+1)/( 1 - 2*x*(k+1)/G(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Mar 23 2013
a(n) is always odd. For odd prime p and n >= 1, a((p-1)*n) = 0 (mod p). - _Peter Bala_, Sep 18 2013
G.f.: T(0)/(1-x), where T(k) = 1 - 2*x^2*(k+1)^2/( 2*x^2*(k+1)^2 - (1-x-3*x*k)*(1-4*x-3*x*k)/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 14 2013
a(n) = log(2)* Integral_{x>=0} floor(x)^n * 2^(-x) dx. - _Peter Bala_, Feb 06 2015
For n > 0, a(n) = Re(polygamma(n, i*log(2)/(2*Pi))/(2*Pi*i)^(n+1)) - n!/(2*log(2)^(n+1)). - _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Oct 15 2015
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n}(k*b2(k-1)*(k)!*stirling2(n, k)), n>0, a(0)=1, where b2(n) is the n-th Bernoulli number of the second kind. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Nov 21 2016
a(n) = A074206(k) for squarefree k with n prime factors. In particular a(n) = A074206(A002110(n)). - _Amiram Eldar_, May 13 2019
For n >0, a(n) = -(-1)^n / 2 * PHI(2, -n, 0), where PHI(z, s, a) is the Lerch Zeta function. - _Federico Provvedi_, Sep 05 2020
a(n) = Sum_{s in S_n} Product_{i=1..n} binomial(i,s(i)-1), where s ranges over the set S_n of permutations of [n]. - _Jose A. Rodriguez_, Feb 02 2021

A000671.name: Boron trees with n nodes = n-node rooted trees with deg <=3 at root and out-degree <=2 elsewhere.
formula: Another g.f.: let B0(x) = 1+x, G036656(x) = g.f. for A036656, G036657(x) = g.f. for A036657.

Then g.f.: x*(cycle_index(S3, B0)+cycle_index(S3, G036656)+cycle_index(S3, G036657)+cycle_index(S2, B0)*(G036656+G036657)+cycle_index(S2, G036656)*(G036657+B0)+cycle_index(S2, G036657)*(B0+G036656)+B0*G036656*G036657), where cycle_index(Sk, f) means apply the cycle index for the symmetric group S_k to f(x).
E.g. cycle_index(S2, f) = (1/2!)*(f^2+subs(x=x^2, f), cycle_index(S3, f) = (1/3!)*(f^3+3*subs(x=x^2, f)*f+2*subs(x=x^3, f)).

A000672.name: Number of 3-valent trees (= boron trees or binary trees) with n nodes.
formula: Rains and Sloane give a g.f.

a(0)=a(1)=a(2)=1, a(n) = 2*b(n+1) - b(n+2) + b((n+1)/2) - 2*C(1+b(n/3), 3) - Sum_{i=1..[(n-1)/2]} C(b(i), 2)*b(n-2*i) + Sum_{i=1..[n/3]} b(i) Sum_{j=i..[(n-i)/2]} b(j)*b(n-i-j), where b(x) = A001190(x+1) if x is an integer, otherwise 0 (Cyvin et al.) [Index of A001190 shifted by _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 08 2010]

A000673.name: Number of bicentered 3-valent (or boron, or binary) trees with n nodes.

A000674.name: Boustrophedon transform of 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, ...
formula: Binomial convolution of A000111 and A040000. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 30 2014

A000675.name: Number of centered 3-valent (or boron, or binary) trees with n nodes.

A000676.name: Number of centered trees with n nodes.

A000677.name: Number of bicentered trees with n nodes.

A000678.name: Number of carbon (rooted) trees with n carbon atoms = unordered 4-tuples of ternary trees.
formula: G.f.: A(x) = x*cycle_index(S4, B(x)), B(x) = g.f. for A000598.

A000680.name: a(n) = (2n)!/2^n.
formula: E.g.f.: 1/(1 - x^2/2) (with interpolating zeros). - _Paul Barry_, May 26 2003

a(n) = polygorial(n, 6) = (A000142(n)/A000079(n))*A001813(n) = (n!/2^n)*Product_{i=0..n-1} (4*i + 2) = (n!/2^n)*4^n*Pochhammer(1/2, n) = gamma(2*n+1)/2^n. - Daniel Dockery (peritus(AT)gmail.com), Jun 13 2003

a(n) = A087127(n,2*n) = Sum_{i=0..2*n} (-1)^(2*n-i)*binomial(2*n, i)*binomial(i+2, 2)^n. Let T(n,k,j) = ((n - k + j)*(2*n - 2*k + 1))^n*binomial(2*n, 2*k-j+1) then a(n) = Sum{k=0..n} (T(n,k,1) - T(n,k,0)). For example a(12) = A087127(12,24) = Sum_{k=0..12} (T(12,k,1) - T(12,k,0)) = 24!/2^12. - _André F. Labossière_, Mar 29 2004 [Corrected by _Jianing Song_, Jan 08 2019]
For even n, a(n) = binomial(2n, n)*(a(n/2))^2. For odd n, a(n) = binomial(2n, n+1)*a((n+1)/2)*a((n-1)/2). For positive n, a(n) = binomial(2n, 2)*a(n-1) with a(0) = 1. - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Nov 17 2009
a(n) = Product_{k = 0..n-1} (T(n) - T(k)), where T(n) = n*(n + 1)/2 is the n-th triangular number.

Thus we may view a(n) as a generalized factorial function associated with the triangular numbers A000217. Cf. A010050. The corresponding generalized binomial coefficients a(n)/(a(k)*a(n-k)) are triangle A086645. Also cf. A186432.
G.f.: 1/U(0) where U(k)= x*(2*k - 1)*k + 1 - x*(2*k + 1)*(k + 1)/U(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 28 2012
a(n) = n!*(product of the first n odd integers). - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Nov 28 2012
a(0) = 1, a(n) = a(n-1)*T(2*n-1), where T(n) is the n-th triangular number. For example: a(4) = a(3)*T(7) = 90*28 = 2520. - _Enric Reverter i Bigas_, Jun 24 2013
E.g.f.: 1/(1 - x/(1 - 2*x/(1 - 3*x/(1 - 4*x/(1 - 5*x/(1 - ...)))))), a continued fraction. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 10 2017

A000681.name: Number of n X n matrices with nonnegative entries and every row and column sum 2.
formula: Sum_{n >= 0} a(n) x^n / n!^2 = exp(x/2) / sqrt(1-x).
a(n) is asymptotic to c/sqrt(n)*(n!)^2 where c=0.93019... - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 25 2004
In Cloitre's formula is c = exp(1/2)/sqrt(Pi) = 0.9301913671026328586. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 12 2013
E.g.f.: 2/((2-x)*W(0)), where W(k) = 1 - (2*k+1)*x/(2-x-2*(k+1)*x/W(k+1)); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 25 2014

A000682.name: Semi-meanders: number of ways a semi-infinite directed curve can cross a straight line n times.
formula: a(n) = A000136(n)/n. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 06 2019, from formula in A000136.

A000683.name: Number of colorings of labeled graphs on n nodes using exactly 2 colors, divided by 4.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 2^(n^2/4+n-3/2)/sqrt(Pi*n), where c = Sum_{k = -infinity..infinity} 2^(-k^2) = 2.128936827211877... if n is even and c = Sum_{k = -infinity..infinity} 2^(-(k+1/2)^2) = 2.12893125051302... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 24 2013

A000684.name: Number of colored labeled n-node graphs with 2 interchangeable colors.
formula: G.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=1} x^n/(1 - 2^n*x)^n. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Sep 14 2009
G.f.: 1/(W(0)-x) where W(k) = x*(x*2^k-1)^k - (x*2^(k+1)-1)^(k+1) + x*((2*x*2^k-1)^(2*k+2))/W(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 17 2012

Let E(x) = Sum_{n >= 0} x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)). Then a generating function for this sequence (but with an offset of 0) is E(x)*E(2*x) = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n+1)*x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)) = 1 + 3*x + 13*x^2/(2!*2) + 81*x^3/(3!*2^3) + 721*x^4/(4!*2^6) + .... Cf. A134531. (End)

A000685.name: Number of 3-colored labeled graphs on n nodes, divided by 3.
formula: a(n) = (1/3)Sum_{j=0..n} binomial(n, j)*2^(j(n-j))*c(j) where c(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} binomial(n, i)*2^(i(n-i)) = A047863(n). - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 06 2004

a(n) = 1/3*A191371(n). Let E(x) = Sum_{n >= 0} x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)). Then a generating function for this sequence is 1/3*E(x)^3 - 1/3 = Sum_{n >= 1} a(n)*x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)) = x + 5*x^2/(2!*2) + 41*x^3/(3!*2^3) + .... In general, E(x)^k, k = 1, 2, ..., is a generating function for labeled k-colored graphs (see Read). For examples see A047863 (k = 2), A191371 (k = 3) and A223887 (k = 4). (End)

A000686.name: Number of 4-colored labeled graphs on n nodes, divided by 4.
formula: a(n) = (1/4)Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, k)*2^(k(n-k))*b(k), where b(0)=1 and b(k)=3*A000685(k) for k > 0. - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 06 2004
a(n) = (1/4)*Sum_{k = 0..n} binomial(n,k)*2^(k*(n-k))*b(k)*b(n-k), where b(n) := Sum_{k = 0..n} binomial(n,k)*2^(k*(n-k)).
Let E(x) = Sum_{n >= 0} x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)). Then a generating function for this sequence is 1/4*(E(x)^4 - 1) = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n)*x^n/(n!*2^C(n,2)) = x + 7*x^2/(2!*2) + 85*x^3/(3!*2^3) + .... (End)

A000687.name: Boustrophedon transform (first version) of Fibonacci numbers 0,1,1,2,3,5,...
formula: E.g.f.: (sec(x) + tan(x))*(((exp(a*x) - 1)/a - (exp(b*x) - 1)/b)/(a - b) + 1), where a = (1 + sqrt(5))/2 and b = (1 - sqrt(5))/2. - _Petros Hadjicostas_, Feb 16 2021

A000688.name: Number of Abelian groups of order n; number of factorizations of n into prime powers.
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^k) = number of partitions of k = A000041(k); a(mn) = a(m)a(n) if (m, n) = 1.
n  = product(prime(j)^e(j), j = 1..N(n)), N(n) = A001221(n). See the Richert reference, quoting A. Speiser's book on finite groups (in German, p. 51 in words). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jul 23 2011

In terms of the cycle index of the symmetric group: prod_{q=1}^m [z^{v_q}] Z(S_v) 1/(1-z) where v is the maximum exponent of any prime in the prime factorization of n, v_q are the exponents of the prime factors, and Z(S_v) is the cycle index of the symmetric group on v elements. - _Marko Riedel_, Oct 03 2014
Dirichlet g.f.: sum_{n >= 1} a(n)/n^s = product_{k >= 1} zeta(ks) [Kendall]. - _Álvar Ibeas_, Nov 05 2014

a(n)=2 for all n in A054753 and for all n in A085987.  a(n)=3 for all n in A030078 and for all n in A065036.  a(n)=4 for all n in A085986.  a(n)=5 for all n in A030514 and for all n in A178739.  a(n)=6 for all n in A143610. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 05 2016

A000689.name: Final decimal digit of 2^n.
formula: a(n) = (1/6)*{8*(n mod 4)-[(n+1) mod 4]+2*[(n+2) mod 4]+11*[(n+3) mod 4]}-5*{1-[((n+1)!+1) mod (n+1)]}, with n>=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Jun 25 2007; corrected by _Paolo P. Lava_, Mar 23 2010

A000690.name: Landau's approximation to population of x^2 + y^2.
formula: a(n) = round(b*2^n/sqrt(log(2^n))) where b=0.764223654... is the Landau-Ramanujan constant (A064533).

A000691.name: Ramanujan's approximation to population of x^2 + y^2.

A000692.name: An approximation to population of x^2 + y^2.
formula: a(n)=(b*2^n/sqrt(n*log(2)))*(1+c/(n*log(2))) where b=0.764223654... is the Landau-Ramanujan constant (A064533) and c=0.5819486593... is the second-order Landau-Ramanujan constant (A227158) given by c=(1/2)*(1-log(Pi*e^gamma/(2*L)))-(1/4)deriv(log(prod(1/(1-p^(-2*s)),p prime = 3(mod 4)),s=1) where L is the Lemniscate constant (A064853). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Feb 25 2011

A000693.name: Related to population of numbers of form x^2 + y^2.

A000694.name: Related to population of numbers of form x^2 + y^2.

A000695.name: Moser-de Bruijn sequence: sums of distinct powers of 4.
formula: Numbers k such that the coefficient of x^k is > 0 in prod (n>=0, 1+x^(4^n)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jul 29 2003
For n>=1, a(n) = a(n-1)+(4^t+2)/6, where t is such that 2^t||2n,or t=A007814(2n). a(n)=(A145812(n+1)-1)/2. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Nov 07 2008

To get a(n), write n as Sum b_j*2^j, then a(n) = Sum b_j*2^(2j). The Diophantine equation a(k)+2a(l)=n has the unique solution: k=Sum b_(2j)*2^j, l=Sum b_(2j+1)*2^j. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Nov 10 2008
If a(k)*a(l)=a(m), then k*l=m (inverse, generally speaking, is not true). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Nov 21 2008
Let F(x) be the generating function, then F(x)*F(x^2)=1/(1-x). - _Joerg Arndt_, May 12 2010

a(n+1) = (a(n) + 1/3) & -1/3, where & is bitwise AND, -1/3 is represented as the infinite dyadic ...010101 (just as -1 is ...111111 in two's complement) and +1/3 is ...101011. - _Marc LeBrun_, Sep 30 2010
a(n) = Sum_k>=0 {A030308(n,k)*b(k)} with b(k)=4^k=A000302(k). - _Philippe Deléham_, Oct 18 2011
liminf a(n)/n^2 = 1/3 and limsup a(n)/n^2 = 1. - _Gheorghe Coserea_, Sep 15 2015

Let f(x) = Sum(k=-inf..inf, floor(x*2^k)/4^k)/2. Then f(x) is a real-valued extension of a(n), which a(n) approximates in the sense that f(x) = lim(k->inf, a(floor(x*2^k))/a(2^k)). - _Velin Yanev_, Nov 28 2016
G.f. A(x) satisfies x / (1 - x^2) = A(x) - 4 * (1 + x) * A(x^2). - _Michael Somos_, Nov 30 2016
a(2^k) = 4^k. a(n + 2^k) = a(n) + a(2^k) for 2^k > n >= 1. - _David A. Corneth_, Oct 16 2018

A000697.name: Boustrophedon transform of 1, 1, 4, 9, 16, ...
formula: E.g.f.: (1 + exp(x)*x*(1 + x))*(sec(x) + tan(x)). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 29 2014
a(n) ~ n! * (4 + exp(Pi/2)*Pi*(2 + Pi)) * 2^n / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000698.name: A problem of configurations: a(0) = 1; for n>0, a(n) = (2n-1)!! - Sum_{k=1..n-1} (2k-1)!! a(n-k). Also the number of shellings of an n-cube, divided by 2^n n!.
formula: a(n+1) = Sum_{k=0..n} A089949(n, k)*2^k. - _Philippe Deléham_, Aug 15 2005
G.f.: 1 + x * B(x) * C(x) where B(x) is the g.f. for A001147 and C(x) is the g.f. for A005416. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 08 2011
G.f.: 1+x/W(0); where W(k)=1+x+x*2k-x*(2k+3)/W(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 17 2011
Recurrence relation: a(n+1) = (2*n-1)*a(n) + Sum_{k = 1..n} a(k)*a(n+1-k) for n >= 0 and a(1) = 1.

The o.g.f. B(x) = Sum_{n>=1} a(n)*x^(2*n-1) = x + 2*x^3 + 10*x^5 + 74*x^7 + ... satisfies the Riccati differential equation y'(x) = -1/x^2 + 1/x^3*y(x) - 1/x^2*y(x)^2 with initial condition y(0) = 0 (Cf. A005412). The solution is B(x) = 1/z(x) + 1/x , where z(x) = - Sum{n>=0} A001147(n) * x^(2*n+1) = -(x + x^3 + 3*x^5 + 15*x^7 +...). The function b(x) = - B(1/x) satisfies b'(x) = -1 - (x + b(x))*b(x). Hence the differential operator (D^2 + x*D + 1), where D = d/dx, factorizes as (D - a(x))*(D - b(x)), where a(x) = -(x + b(x)), as conjectured by [Edgar, Problem 4.32]. For a refinement of this sequence see A053979. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 22 2011
From _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 19 2012, Oct 24 2012, Mar 19 2013, May 20 2013, May 29 2013, Aug 04 2013, Aug 05 2013: (Start) Continued Fractions:
G.f.: 2 - 1/B(x) where B(x) is the g.f. of A001147.
G.f.: 1 + x/(1-2*x*B(x)) where B(x) is the g.f. of A167872. (End)

G.f.: 1/x + (sqrt(2/Pi) * exp(1/(2*x)) * sqrt[-1/x])/Erfc(sqrt(-1/x)/sqrt(2)) where Erfc(z) = 1 - Erf(z) is the complementary error function, and Erf(z) is the integral of the Gaussian distribution. This generating function is obtained from the generating functional of (4-dimensional) QED, evaluated in dimension 0 for the 2-point function, without the modification implementing Furry theorem. - _Robert Coquereaux_, Sep 14 2014

A000699.name: Number of irreducible chord diagrams with 2n nodes.
formula: a(n) = (n-1)*Sum_{i=1..n-1} a(i)*a(n-i) for n > 1, with a(1) = a(0) = 1. [Modified to include a(0) = 1. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 06 2020]
G.f. satisfies: A(x) = 1 + x + x^2*[d/dx (A(x) - 1)^2/x]. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 31 2010 [Modified to include a(0) = 1. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 06 2020]
G.f. A(x) satisfies: 1 = A(x) - x/(A(x) - 2*x/(A(x) - 3*x/(A(x) - 4*x/(A(x) - 5*x/(A(x) - ...))))), a continued fraction relation. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 04 2020

A000700.name: Expansion of Product_{k>=0} (1 + x^(2k+1)); number of partitions of n into distinct odd parts; number of self-conjugate partitions; number of symmetric Ferrers graphs with n nodes.
formula: G.f.: Product_{k>=1}(1+x^(2*k-1)) = Sum_{k>=0} x^(k^2)/Product_{i=1..k} (1-x^(2*i)). - Euler (Hardy and Wright, Theorem 345)
Expansion of chi(q) = (-q; q^2)_oo = f(q) / f(-q^2) = phi(q) / f(q) = f(-q^2) / psi(-q) = phi(-q^2) / f(-q) = psi(q) / f(-q^4), where phi(), chi(), psi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions.
Let b(n)=A081360(n); then Sum_{k=0..n} b(k)*a(n-k) = 0, for n>0. - _John W. Layman_, Apr 26 2000
Expansion of q^(1/24) * eta(q^2)^2 /(eta(q) * eta(q^4)) in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Jun 11 2004

Asymptotics: a(n) ~ exp(Pi*l_n)/(2*24^(1/4)*l_n^(3/2)) where l_n = (n-1/24)^(1/2) (Ayoub). The asymptotic formula in Ayoub is incorrect, as that would imply faster growth than the total number of partitions. (It was quoted correctly, the book is just wrong, not sure what the correct asymptotic is.) - _Edward Early_, Nov 15 2002. Right formula is a(n) ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(n/6)) / (2*24^(1/4)*n^(3/4)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 23 2014
a(n) = 1/n*Sum_{k = 1..n} (-1)^(k+1)*b(k)*a(n-k), n>1, a(0) = 1, b(n) = A000593(n) = sum of odd divisors of n. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 19 2002 [see Theorem 2(a) in N. Robbins's article]
For n>0: a(n) = b(n, 1) where b(n, k) = if k<n then b(n-k, k+2) + b(n, k+2) else (n mod 2) * 0^(k-n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 26 2003
Expansion of q^(1/24) * (m * (1 - m) / 16)^(-1/24) in powers of q where m = k^2 is the parameter and q is the nome for Jacobian elliptic functions.
Given g.f. A(x), B(q) = (1/q)* A(q^3)^8 satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^2)) where f(u, v) = u*v * (u - v^2) * (v - u^2) - (4 * (1 - u*v))^2. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 16 2007
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (2304 t)) = f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 16 2007
Expansion of q^(1/24)*f(t) in powers of q = exp(Pi*i*t) where f() is Weber's function. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 18 2007
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} (-1)^(n-k) A008284(n,k). - _Jeremy L. Martin_, Jul 06 2013
a(n) = S(n,1), where S(n,m) = Sum_{k=m..n/2} (-1)^(k+1)*S(n-k,k) + (-1)^(n+1), S(n,n)=(-1)^(n+1), S(0,m)=1, S(n,m)=0 for n<m. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Sep 07 2014
G.f.: Product_{k>0} (1 + x^(2*k-1)) = Product_{k>0} (1 - (-x)^k) / (1 - (-x)^(2*k)) = Product_{k>0} 1 / (1 + (-x)^k). - _Michael Somos_, Nov 08 2014
Given g.f. A(x), B(q) = (1/q) * A(q^24) / 2^(1/4) satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^5)) where f(u, v) = u^6 + v^6 + 2*u*v * (1 - (u*v)^4). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 14 2019

A000701.name: One half of number of non-self-conjugate partitions; also half of number of asymmetric Ferrers graphs with n nodes.

A000702.name: a(n) is the number of conjugacy classes in the alternating group A_n.
formula: a(n) = (p(n) + 3Q(n))/2 for n>1 where p(n) denotes the number of unrestricted partitions of n (A000041) and Q(n) the number of partitions of n into distinct odd parts (A000700). [Denes-Erdős-Turan]
Sum_{r>=0} (-1)^r*a(n-(3r^2 +- r)/2) = 3(-1)^t if n = 2t^2 or 0 otherwise, where p(u) and a(u) are taken as 0 unless u is a nonnegative integer and t = 1,2,3,... [Girse]

A000703.name: Chromatic number (or Heawood number) of nonorientable surface with n crosscaps.

A000704.name: Number of degree-n even permutations of order dividing 2.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i = 0..floor(n/4)} C(n, 4i)*(4i-1)!!. - _Ralf Stephan_, May 08 2007 [Corrected by _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 01 2011]

A000705.name: n-th superior highly composite number A002201(n) is product of first n terms of this sequence.

A000706.name: Expansion of modular function 1/E_3 (cf. A013973).
formula: Expansion of 1 / R(q) in powers of q where R() is a Ramanujan Lambert series.

A000707.name: Number of permutations of [1,2,...,n] with n-1 inversions.
formula: a(n) = 2^(2*n-2)/sqrt(Pi*n)*Q*(1+O(n^(-1))), where Q is a digital search tree constant, Q = product(1-1/(2^n),n=1..infinity) = QPochhammer[1/2, 1/2] = 0.288788095... (see A048651), corrected and extended by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 16 2014

A000708.name: a(n) = E(n+1) - 2*E(n), where E(i) is the Euler number A000111(i).
formula: a(n) = 2*abs(PolyLog(-n-1, i)) - 4*abs(PolyLog(-n, i)) for n > 0, with a(0) = -1. - _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 02 2017

A000709.name: Related to population of numbers of form x^2 + y^2.
formula: a(n) = int (1/sqrt(log(u)), u=1..2^(n-1))))). - Based on _Alois P. Heinz_'s Maple program, _Alonso del Arte_, Oct 24 2014

A000710.name: Number of partitions of n, with two kinds of 1, 2, 3 and 4.

A000711.name: Number of partitions of n, with three kinds of 1,2,3 and 4 and two kinds of 5,6,7,...

A000712.name: Number of partitions of n into parts of 2 kinds.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} p(k)*p(n-k), where p(n) = A000041(n).
Euler transform of period 1 sequence [ 2, 2, 2, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 22 2003

More precise asymptotics: a(n) ~ exp(2*Pi*sqrt(n/3)) / (4*3^(3/4)*n^(5/4)) * (1 - (Pi/(12*sqrt(3)) + 15*sqrt(3)/(16*Pi)) / sqrt(n) + (Pi^2/864 + 315/(512*Pi^2) + 35/192)/n). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 22 2017
a(n) is odd iff n = 2*m and p(m) is odd.
Conjecture: a(n) is divisible by 5 when n is congruent to 2, 3 or 4 modulo 5 (checked up to n = 1000). (End)
G.f.: exp(2*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 06 2018

A000713.name: EULER transform of 3, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, ...
formula: G.f.: A(x)/(1-x) where A(x) is g.f. for A000712. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Apr 19 2012.

A000714.name: Number of partitions of n, with three kinds of 1 and 2 and two kinds of 3,4,5,....
formula: a(n) ~ 3^(1/4) * exp(2*Pi*sqrt(n/3)) / (8 * Pi^2 * n^(1/4)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 18 2015

A000715.name: Number of partitions of n, with three kinds of 1,2 and 3 and two kinds of 4,5,6,....
formula: a(n) ~ exp(2*Pi*sqrt(n/3)) * n^(1/4) / (8 * 3^(1/4) * Pi^3). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 18 2015

A000716.name: Number of partitions of n into parts of 3 kinds.
formula: a(n) ~ exp(Pi * sqrt(2*n)) / (8 * sqrt(2) * n^(3/2)) * (1 - (3/Pi + Pi/8) / sqrt(2*n)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 28 2015, extended Jan 16 2017
G.f.: exp(3*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 06 2018

A000717.name: Number of graphs with n nodes and floor(n(n-1)/4) edges.

A000718.name: Boustrophedon transform of triangular numbers 1,1,3,6,10,...
formula: a(n) ~ n! * (8 + exp(Pi/2)*Pi*(4+Pi)) * 2^(n-1) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000719.name: Number of disconnected graphs with n nodes.

A000720.name: pi(n), the number of primes <= n. Sometimes called PrimePi(n) to distinguish it from the number 3.14159...
formula: The prime number theorem gives the asymptotic expression a(n) ~ n/log(n).
For x > 1, pi(x) < (x / log x) * (1 + 3/(2 log x)). For x >= 59, pi(x) > (x / log x) * (1 + 1/(2 log x)). [Rosser and Schoenfeld]
For n > 1, A138194(n) <= a(n) <= A138195(n) (Tschebyscheff, 1850). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 04 2008

For n >= 33, a(n) = 1 + Sum_{j=3..n} ((j-2)! - j*floor((j-2)!/j)) (Hardy and Wright); for n >= 1, a(n) = n - 1 + Sum_{j=2..n} (floor((2 - Sum_{i=1..j} (floor(j/i)-floor((j-1)/i)))/j)) (Ruiz and Sondow 2000). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 31 2003
G.f.: Sum_{p prime} x^p/(1-x) = b(x)/(1-x), where b(x) is the g.f. for A010051. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 15 2006
Let pf(n) denote the set of prime factors of an integer n. Then a(n) = card(pf(n!/floor(n/2)!). - _Peter Luschny_, Mar 13 2011
a(n) = -Sum_{p <= n} mu(p). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Jan 04 2013
a(n) = (1/2)*Sum_{p <= n} (mu(p)*d(p)*sigma(p)*phi(p)) + sum_{p <= n} p^2. - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Jan 04 2013
a(1) = 0 and then, for all k >= 1, repeat k A001223(k) times. - _Jean-Christophe Hervé_, Oct 29 2013
a(n) = n/(log(n) - 1 - Sum_{k=1..m} A233824(k)/log(n)^k + O(1/log(n)^{m+1})) for m > 0. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Dec 19 2013
a(n) = Sum_{j=2..n} H(-sin^2 (Pi*(Gamma(j)+1)/j)) where H(x) is the Heaviside step function, taking H(0)=1. - _Keshav Raghavan_, Jun 18 2016
a(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} A001221(m) * A002321(floor(n/m)) where A002321() is the Mertens function.
a(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} |A143519(m)| * A002819(floor(n/m)) where A002819() is the Liouville Lambda summatory function and |x| is the absolute value of x.
a(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} A137851(m)/m * H(floor(n/m)) where H(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} 1/m is the harmonic number function.
a(n) = Sum_{m=1..log_2(n)} A008683(m) * A025528(floor(n^(1/m))) where A008683() is the Moebius mu function and A025528() is the prime-power counting function.
Sum_{k=2..n} 1/a(k) ~ (1/2) * log(n)^2 + O(log(n)) (de Koninck and Ivić, 1980). - _Amiram Eldar_, Mar 08 2021

A000721.name: Number of balanced Boolean functions of n variables.

A000722.name: Number of invertible Boolean functions of n variables: a(n) = (2^n)!.

A000723.name: Invertible Boolean functions of n variables.

A000724.name: Invertible Boolean functions of n variables.

A000725.name: Invertible Boolean functions of n variables.

A000726.name: Number of partitions of n in which no parts are multiples of 3.
formula: G.f.: 1/(Product_{k>=1} (1-x^(3*k-1))*(1-x^(3*k-2))) = Product_{k>=1} (1 + x^k + x^(2*k)) (where 1 + x + x^2 is the 3rd cyclotomic polynomial).
Given g.f. A(x) then B(x)=x*A(x^6)^2 satisfies 0=f(B(x), B(x^2), B(x^4)) where f(u,v,w)= +v^2 +v*w^2 -v*u^2 +3*u^2*w^2. - _Michael Somos_, May 28 2006
G.f.: P(x^3)/P(x) where P(x)=prod(k>=1, 1-x^k ). - _Joerg Arndt_, Jun 21 2011
G.f.: exp(Sum_{k>=1} x^k*(1 + x^k)/(k*(1 - x^(3*k)))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 15 2018

A000727.name: Expansion of Product_{k >= 1} (1-x^k)^4.
formula: Euler transform of period 1 sequence [-4, -4, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 02 2005
Given g.f. A(x), then B(q) = q * A(q^3)^2 satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^2), B(q^4)) where f(u, v, w) = w*u^2 - v^3 + 16 * u*w^2. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 02 2005

a(n) = b(6*n + 1) where b() is multiplicative with b(2^e) = b(3^e) = 0^e, b(p^e) = b(p) * b(p^(e-1)) - p * b(p^(e-2)), b(p) = 0 if p == 5 (mod 6), b(p) = 2*x where p = x^2 + 3*y^2 == 1 (mod 6) and x == 1 (mod 3). - _Michael Somos_, Aug 23 2006
Coefficients of L-series for elliptic curve "36a1": y^2 = x^3 + 1. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 01 2004

a(n) = (-1)^n * A187076(n). a(2*n + 1) = -4 * A187150(n). a(25*n + 9) = a(25*n + 14) = a(25*n + 19) = a(25*n + 24) = 0. a(25*n + 4) = -5 * a(n). Convolution inverse of A023003. Convolution square of A002107. Convolution square is A000731.
a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(4/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 26 2017
G.f.: exp(-4*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

Let M = p_1*...*p_k be a positive integer whose prime factors p_i (not necessarily distinct) are all congruent to 5 (mod 6). Then a( M^2*n + (M^2 - 1)/6 ) = (-1)^k*M*a(n). See Cooper et al., equation 4. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 01 2020

A000728.name: Expansion of Product_{n>=1} (1-x^n)^5.
formula: a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(5/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 26 2017
G.f.: exp(-5*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

A000729.name: Expansion of Product_{k >= 1} (1 - x^k)^6.
formula: Expansion of q^(-1/4)/16 * theta_2(q)^4 * theta_3(q) * theta_4(q) in powers of q. - [Dickson, v. 3, p. 134] from Stieltjes footnote 160. _Michael Somos_, Jun 18 2012
Expansion of q^(-1/2) / 4 * k * k' * (K / (pi/2))^3 in powers of q^2 where k, k', K are Jacobi elliptic functions. - _Michael Somos_, Jun 22 2012
Given g.f. A(x), then A(q^4) = f(-q^4)^6 = phi(q) * phi(-q) * psi(q^2)^4 where phi(), psi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 23 2006

a(n) = b(4*n + 1) where b(n) is multiplicative with b(2^e) = 0^e, b(p^e) = p^e * (1 + (-1)^e) / 2 if p == 3 (mod 4), b(p^e) = b(p) * b(p^(e-1)) - b(p^(e-2)) * p^2 if p == 1 (mod 4) and b(p) = (-1)^y * (x^2 - y^2) where p = x^2 + y^2. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 23 2006
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (16 t)) = 64 (t/i)^3 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Aug 24 2012
G.f.: Sum_{k>=0} a(k) * x^(4*k + 1) = (1/2) * Sum_{u,v in Z} (u*u - 4*v*v) * x^(u*u + 4*v*v). - _Michael Somos_, Jun 14 2007
G.f.: eta(x)^6 = Sum_{n>=0} (1+2n)^2*x^(n^2+n) + 2*Sum_{n>=0,k>=1} (1 + 4(n^2+n-k^2))*x^(n^2+n+k^2) - from the Milne and Leininger reference. [_Paul D. Hanna_, Mar 15 2010]
a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(6/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 26 2017
G.f.: exp(-6*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018
Let M be a positive integer whose prime factors are all congruent to 3 (mod 4) - see A004614. Then a( M^2*n + (M^2 - 1)/4 ) = M^2*a(n). See Cooper et al., equation 5. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 01 2020

A000730.name: Expansion of Product_{n>=1} (1 - x^n)^7.
formula: a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(7/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 26 2017
G.f.: exp(-7*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

A000731.name: Expansion of Product (1 - x^k)^8 in powers of x.
formula: Expansion of q^(-1/3) * eta(q)^8 in powers of q.
Expansion of q^(-1/3) * b(q)^3 * c(q) / 3 in powers of q where b(), c() are cubic AGM theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 08 2006
Expansion of q^(-1) * b(q) * c(q)^3 / 27 in powers of q^3 where b(), c() are cubic AGM theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 08 2006

a(n) = b(3*n + 1) where b(n) is multiplicative and b(3^e) = 0^e, b(p^e) = (1 + (-1)^e)/2 * (-1)^(e/2) * p^(3*e/2) if p == 2 (mod 3), b(p^e) = b(p)*b(p^(e-1)) - b(p^(e-2))*p^3 if p == 1 (mod 3) where b(p) = (x^2 - 3*p)*x, 4*p = x^2 + 3*y^2, |x|<|y| and x == 2 (mod 3). - _Michael Somos_, Aug 23 2006
Given g.f. A(x), then B(x) = x * A(x^3) satisfies 0 = f(B(x), B(x^2), B(x^4)) where f(u, v, w) = v^3 - u * w * (u + 16 * w). - _Michael Somos_, Feb 19 2007
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (9 t)) = 81 (t/i)^4 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 29 2011

Sum_{n>=0} a(n) * q^(3*n + 1) = (Sum_{i,j,k in Z} (i-j) * (j-k) * (k-i) * q^((i*i + j*j + k*k) / 2)) / 2 where 0 = i+j+k, i == 1 (mod 3), j == 2 (mod 3), and k == 0 (mod 3). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 22 2014
a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(8/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 27 2017
G.f.: exp(-8*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

Let M = p_1*...*p_k be a positive integer whose prime factors p_i (not necessarily distinct) are all congruent to 2 (mod 3). Then a( M^2*n + (M^2 - 1)/3 ) = (-1)^k*M^3*a(n). See Cooper et al., Theorem 1. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 01 2020

A000732.name: Boustrophedon transform of 1 & primes: 1,2,3,5,7,...
formula: E.g.f.: (sec(x) + tan(x))*(1 + Sum_{k>=1} prime(k)*x^k/k!). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 23 2019

A000735.name: Expansion of Product_{k>=1} (1 - x^k)^12.
formula: Expansion of q^(-1/2) * eta(q)^12 in powers of q.
Euler transform of period 1 sequence [-12, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 21 2005
Given g.f. A(x), then B(q) = q * A(q^2) satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^2), B(q^4)) where f(u, v, w) = u^4*w^2 + 48*(u*v*w)^2 + 4906*u^2*w^4 - u^6. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 21 2005
a(n) = b(2*n + 1) where b(n) is multiplicative with b(2^e) = 0^e, b(p^e) = b(p) * b(p^(e-1)) - p^5 * b(p^(e-2)). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 08 2006
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (4 t)) = 64 (t/i)^6 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Aug 24 2012
Convolution inverse of A005758. Convolution square of A000729.
a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(12/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 26 2017
G.f.: exp(-12*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

A000737.name: Boustrophedon transform of natural numbers, cf. A000027.

A000738.name: Boustrophedon transform (first version) of Fibonacci numbers 0,1,1,2,3,...
formula: E.g.f.: (2/sqrt(5)) * exp(x/2) * sinh((sqrt(5)/2)*x) * (sin(x)+1) / cos(x). - _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 08 2011

A000739.name: Expansion of Product_{k>=1} (1 - x^k)^16.
formula: a(0) = 1, a(n) = -(16/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A000203(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Mar 27 2017
G.f.: exp(-16*Sum_{k>=1} x^k/(k*(1 - x^k))). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2018

A000740.name: Number of 2n-bead balanced binary necklaces of fundamental period 2n, equivalent to reversed complement; also Dirichlet convolution of b_n=2^(n-1) with mu(n); also number of components of Mandelbrot set corresponding to Julia sets with an attractive n-cycle.
formula: a(n) = sum_{d|n} mu(n/d)*2^(d-1), Mobius transform of A011782. Furthermore, sum_{d|n} a(d) = 2^{n-1}.
Recurrence relation: a(n) = 2^(n-1) - Sum_{d|n,d>1} a(n/d). (Lafayette College Problem Group; see the Maple program). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 27 2007

A000741.name: Number of compositions of n into 3 ordered relatively prime parts.

A000742.name: Number of compositions of n into 4 ordered relatively prime parts.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} mu(k) * x^(4*k) / (1 - x^k)^4. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2020

A000743.name: Number of compositions of n into 5 ordered relatively prime parts.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} mu(k) * x^(5*k) / (1 - x^k)^5. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Feb 05 2020

A000744.name: Boustrophedon transform (second version) of Fibonacci numbers 1,1,2,3,...
formula: a(n) ~ n! * (sqrt(5) - 1 + (1+sqrt(5)) * exp(sqrt(5)*Pi/2)) * 2^(n+1) / (sqrt(5) * exp((sqrt(5)-1)*Pi/4) * Pi^(n+1)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000745.name: Boustrophedon transform of squares.
formula: a(n) ~ n! * (6 + Pi + 4/Pi) * exp(Pi/2) * 2^n / Pi^n. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000746.name: Boustrophedon transform of triangular numbers.
formula: a(n) ~ n! * (Pi^2 + 8*Pi + 8) * exp(Pi/2) * 2^(n-1) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000747.name: Boustrophedon transform of primes.
formula: E.g.f.: (sec(x) + tan(x)) * Sum_{k>=0} prime(k+1)*x^k/k!. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jun 26 2018

A000748.name: Expansion of bracket function.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(k,n-k)*(-3)^(k) for n > 0; a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Feb 07 2011
G.f.: G(0)/2, where G(k) = 1 + 1/( 1 - 3*x*(2*k+1 + x)/(3*x*(2*k+2 + x) - 1/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Feb 09 2014

A000749.name: a(n) = 4*a(n-1) - 6*a(n-2) + 4*a(n-3), n > 3, with a(0)=a(1)=a(2)=0, a(3)=1.
formula: Without the two initial zeros, binomial transform of A007877. - _Henry Bottomley_, Jun 04 2001
a(n) = 2^n/4 - 2^(n/2)*sin(Pi*n/4)/2 - 0^n/4. a(n+1) is the binomial transform of A021913. - _Paul Barry_, Aug 30 2004
a(n; t, s) = a(n-1; t, s) + a(n-1; t+1, s+t+1) where t is the trace and s is the subtrace.
Without the initial three zeros, = binomial transform of [1, 3, 3, 1, 1, 3, 3, 1, 1, 3, 3, 1, 1, 3, 3, 1, 3, ...]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jun 19 2008
where H_1=A038503, H_2=A038504, H_3=A038505. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jun 14 2017

A000752.name: Boustrophedon transform of powers of 2.
formula: a(n) ~ n! * exp(Pi) * 2^(n+2) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 12 2015

A000753.name: Boustrophedon transform of Catalan numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: (sec(x) + tan(x))*exp(2*x)*(BesselI(0,2*x) - BesselI(1,2*x)). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 30 2014
a(n) ~ n! * exp(Pi) * (BesselI(0, Pi) - BesselI(1, Pi)) * 2^(n+2) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 30 2014

A000754.name: Boustrophedon transform of odd numbers.
formula: a(n) ~ n! * (Pi+1) * exp(Pi/2) * 2^(n+2) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 30 2014

A000755.name: No-3-in-line problem on n X n grid: total number of ways of placing 2n points on n X n grid so no 3 are in a line. No symmetries are taken into account.

A000756.name: Boustrophedon transform of sequence 1,1,0,0,0,0,...
formula: E.g.f.: (1 + x)*(1 + 2*x/(U(0) - x)), where U(k) = 4*k + 2 - x^2/U(k+1); (continued fraction, 1-step). (End)
For n > 0: a(n) = A000111(n) + n*A000111(n-1). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 03 2013

A000757.name: Number of cyclic permutations of [n] with no i->i+1 (mod n)
formula: a(n) = n-th forward difference of [1, 1, 1, 2, 6, 24, ...] (factorials A000142 with 1 prepended). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 28 2011
a(n) = sum(((-1)^(n-j))*D(j-1),j=3..n), n>=3, with the derangements numbers (subfactorials) D(n)=A000166(n).

A000758.name: Related to cumulative height of rooted plane trees.

A000759.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on cubic lattice ending at point with x=0.

A000760.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on cubic lattice ending at point with x=1.

A000761.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on cubic lattice ending at point with x=2.

A000762.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on cubic lattice ending at point with x=3.

A000763.name: Number of interval orders constructed from n intervals of generic lengths.
formula: E.g.f. E(x) satisfies E'/E = y^2, where y=1+x+5*x^2/2+... is defined by y*(2-exp(x*y))=1.

A000765.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on f.c.c. lattice ending at point with x = 0.

A000766.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on f.c.c. lattice ending at point with x = 1.

A000767.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on f.c.c. lattice ending at point with x = 2.

A000768.name: Number of n-step self-avoiding walks on f.c.c. lattice ending at point with x = 3.

A000769.name: No-3-in-line problem: number of inequivalent ways of placing 2n points on an n X n grid so that no 3 are in a line.

A000770.name: Stirling numbers of the second kind, S(n,6).
formula: a(n) = det(|s(i+6,j+5)|, 1 <= i,j <= n-6), where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 06 2013

A000771.name: Stirling numbers of second kind, S(n,7).
formula: a(n) = det(|s(i+7,j+6)|, 1 <= i,j <= n-7), where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 06 2013

A000772.name: E.g.f. exp(tan(x) + sec(x) - 1).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} A147315(n-1,k-1), n>0, a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Mar 10 2011
a(n) = D^n(exp(x)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator (1+x+x^2/2!)*d/dx. Cf. A000110 and A094198. See also A185422. - _Peter Bala_, Nov 25 2011
a(n) ~ 2^n * exp(2/Pi - 1 + 4*sqrt(n/Pi) - n) * n^(n - 1/4) / Pi^(n + 1/4). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 27 2020

A000773.name: Number of numbers == 0 (mod 3) in range 2^n to 2^(n+1) with odd number of 1's in binary expansion.
formula: a(n) = a(n-1) + 2 * a(n-2) + 3^(n/2) * (1 + (-1)^n) / 18 for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 23 2014
a(n) = - 6 * a(n-4) - 3 * a(n-3) + 5 * a(n-2) + a(n-1) for n > 4. - _Hugo Pfoertner_, Jun 13 2017

A000774.name: a(n) = n!*(1 + Sum_{i=1..n} 1/i).
formula: a(n) = A000254(n) + n!. - _Mark van Hoeij_, Jul 06 2010
G.f.: 1+x = Sum_{n>=0} a(n) * x^n / Product_{k=1..n+1} (1 + k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Mar 01 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} (k+1)*|s(n,k)|, where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind (A008275). - _Peter Luschny_, Oct 16 2012

A000775.name: a(n) = n! * (n + 1 + 2*Sum_{k=1...n} 1/k).
formula: a(0)=1, a(n+1) = (n+1)*a(n) + (n+3)*n! for n > 0. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jun 10 2011

A000782.name: a(n) = 2*Catalan(n) - Catalan(n-1).
formula: Expansion of x*(1 + x*C)*C^2, where C = (1 - (1 - 4*x)^(1/2))/(2*x) is the g.f. for the Catalan numbers, A000108.
Also, expansion of (1 + x^2*C^2)*C - 1, where C = (1 - (1 - 4*x)^(1/2))/(2*x) is the g.f. for Catalan numbers, A000108.
a(n) = (7*n - 5)/(n + 1) * C(n-1), where C(n) = A000108(n). - _Ralf Stephan_, Jan 13 2004

a(n) = leftmost column term of M^(n-1)*V, where M is a tridiagonal matrix with 1's in the super- and sub-diagonals, (1, 2, 2, 2, ...) in the main diagonal, and the rest zeros; and V is the vector [1, 2, 0, 0, 0,...]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jun 16 2011

A000784.name: Symmetrical planar partitions of n: planar partitions (A000219) that when regarded as 3-D objects have just one symmetry plane).

A000785.name: Number of asymmetrical planar partitions of n: planar partitions (A000219) that when regarded as 3-D objects have no symmetry).

A000786.name: Number of inequivalent planar partitions of n, when considering them as 3D objects.

A000787.name: Strobogrammatic numbers: the same upside down.

A000788.name: Total number of 1's in binary expansions of 0, ..., n.
formula: McIlroy (1974) gives bounds and recurrences. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 24 2014

Stolarsky (1977) studies the asymptotics, and gives at least nine references to earlier work on the problem. I have added all the references that were not here already. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 06 2014
a(n)=n*log_2(n)/2 + O(n); a(2^n)=n*2^(n-1)+1. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Sep 25 2003 (The first result is due to Bellman and Shapiro, - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 24 2014)
a(n)=n*log_2(n)/2+n*F(log_2(n)) where F is a nowhere differentiable continuous function of period 1 (see Allouche & Shallit). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 08 2004
For real n, let f(n) = [n]/2 if [n] even, n-[n+1]/2 otherwise. Then a(n) = Sum_{k>=0} 2^k*f((n+1)/2^k).
(This is the total number of '1' digits occurring in all the numbers with <= m bits.)
Generic formulas for the number of digits >= d in the base p representations of all integers from 0 to n, where 1<= d < p.
a(n) = (1/2)*Sum_{j=1..m+1} (floor(n/p^j + (p-d)/p)*(2n + 2 + ((p-2*d)/p - floor(n/p^j + (p-d)/p))*p^j) - floor(n/p^j)*(2n + 2 - (1+floor(n/p^j)) * p^j)), where m=floor(log_p(n)).

a(n) = (n+1)*F(n,p,d) + (1/2)*Sum_{j=1..m+1} ((((p-2*d)/p)*floor(n/p^j+(p-d)/p) + floor(n/p^j))*p^j - (floor(n/p^j+(p-d)/p)^2 - floor(n/p^j)^2)*p^j), where m=floor(log_p(n)) and F(n,p,d) = number of digits >= d in the base p representation of n.
(This is the total number of digits >= d occurring in all the numbers  with <= m digits in base p representation.)
For n > 0, if n is written as 2^m + r with 0 <= r < 2^m, then a(n) = m*2^(m-1) + r + 1 + a(r). - _Shreevatsa R_, Mar 20 2018

A000789.name: Maximal order of a triangle-free cyclic graph with no independent set of size n.

A000790.name: Primary pretenders: least composite c such that n^c == n (mod c).

A000792.name: a(n) = max{(n - i)*a(i) : i < n}; a(0) = 1.
formula: G.f.: (1 + x + 2*x^2 + x^4)/(1 - 3*x^3). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation.
a(n) = if n <= 2 then n else a(n-1) + Max{gcd(a(i), a(j)) | 0 < i < j < n}. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Feb 08 2002
a(n) = 3^(n - 2 - 2*floor((n - 1)/3))*2^(2 - (n - 1) mod 3) for n > 1. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Nov 11 2007
a(n) = 3^floor(n/3)/(1 - (n mod 3)/4), n > 1. - Kiyoshi Akima (k_akima(AT)hotmail.com), Aug 31 2009
a(n) = 3^(floor((n - 2)/3))*(2 + ((n - 2) mod 3)), n > 1. - Kiyoshi Akima (k_akima(AT)hotmail.com), Aug 31 2009
a(n) = (2^b)*3^(C - (b + d))*(4^d), n > 1, where C = floor((n + 1)/3), b = max(0, ((n + 1) mod 3) - 1), d = max(0, 1 - ((n + 1) mod 3)). - _Jonathan T. Rowell_, Jul 26 2011
3 * a(n) = 2 * a(n+1) if n > 1 and n not divisible by 3. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 23 2014
a(n) = a(n-1) + largest proper divisor of a(n-1), n > 2. - _Ivan Neretin_, Apr 13 2015
a(n) = max{a(i)*a(n-i) : 0 < i < n} for n >= 4. - _Jianing Song_, Feb 15 2020

A000793.name: Landau's function g(n): largest order of permutation of n elements. Equivalently, largest LCM of partitions of n.
formula: Landau: lim_{n->infinity} (log a(n)) / sqrt(n log n) = 1.
For bounds, see the Shah and Massias references.
For n >= 2, a(n) = max_{k} A008475(k) <= n. - _Joerg Arndt_, Nov 13 2016

A000794.name: Permanent of projective plane of order n.

A000795.name: Salié numbers: expansion of cosh x / cos x = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n)*x^(2n)/(2n)!.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k>=0} A086646(n, k). - _Philippe Deléham_, Feb 26 2004

A000796.name: Decimal expansion of Pi (or digits of Pi).
formula: Pi = Integral_{x=-infinity..infinity} dx/(1+x^2). - _Mats Granvik_ and _Gary W. Adamson_, Sep 23 2012
Pi = 3 * Product_{t=img(r),r=(1/2+i*t) root of zeta function} (9+4*t^2)/(1+4*t^2) <=> RH is true. - _Dimitris Valianatos_, May 05 2016
Pi = 2^{k + 1}*arctan(sqrt(2 - a_{k - 1})/a_k) at k >= 2, where a_k = sqrt(2 + a_{k - 1}) and a_1 = sqrt(2). - _Sanjar Abrarov_, Feb 07 2017
a(n) = -10*floor(Pi*10^(-2 + n)) + floor(Pi*10^(-1 + n)) for n > 0. - _Mariusz Iwaniuk_, Apr 28 2017
Pi = Integral_{x = 0..2} sqrt(x/(2 - x)) dx. - _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Nov 20 2017
Pi = lim_{n->infinity} 2/n * Sum_{m=1,n} ( sqrt( (n+1)^2 - m^2 ) - sqrt( n^2 - m^2 ) ). - _Dimitri Papadopoulos_, May 31 2019

More generally, Pi = 4^x*x!/(2*x)! * Sum_{n >= 0} 2^(n+1)*(n+x)!*(n+2*x)!/(2*n+2*x+1)! = 2*4^x*x!^2/(2*x+1)! * hypergeom([2*x+1,1], [x+3/2], 1/2), valid for complex x not in {-1/2,-1,-3/2,-2,...}. Here, x! is shorthand notation for the function Gamma(x+1). This identity may be proved using Gauss's second summation theorem.
Setting x = 3/4 and x = -1/4 (resp. x = 1/4 and x = -3/4) in the above identity leads to series representations for the constant A085565 (resp. A076390). (End)

A000797.name: Numbers that are not the sum of 4 tetrahedral numbers.

A000798.name: Number of different quasi-orders (or topologies, or transitive digraphs) with n labeled elements.
formula: Related to A001035 by a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Stirling2(n, k)*A001035(k).
E.g.f.: A(exp(x) - 1) where A(x) is the e.g.f. for A001035. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Jul 28 2014

A000800.name: Sum of upward diagonals of Eulerian triangle.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k} A173018(n-k, k). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 17 2011
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k)= 1 - x*(k+1)/(1 - x^2*(k+1)/Q(k+1)); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Apr 14 2013
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k)=  1 - x - x*(x+1)*k - x^3*(k+1)^2/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Apr 14 2013

A000802.name: Maximal number of states in deterministic finite automaton accepting a language consisting of some words of length n.

A000804.name: Permanent of a certain cyclic n X n (0,1) matrix.

A000805.name: Permanent of a certain cyclic n X n (0,1) matrix.

A000806.name: Bessel polynomial y_n(-1).
formula: D-finite with recurrence a(n) = (-2*n+1)*a(n-1) + a(n-2). - _T. D. Noe_, Oct 26 2006
If y = x + Sum_{k>1} A000272(k) * x^k/k!, then y = x + Sum{k>1} a(k-2) * (-y)^k/k!. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 07 2005
a(n) = sum_{m=0..n} A001498(n,m)*(-1)^m, n>=0 (alternating row sums of Bessel triangle).
E.g.f. for unsigned version: -exp(sqrt(1-2*x)-1). - _Karol A. Penson_, Mar 20 2010 [gives -1, 1, 0, 1, 5, 36, 329, ... ]
E.g.f. for unsigned version: 1/(sqrt(1-2*x))*exp(sqrt(1-2*x)-1). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 03 2012
G.f.: 1/G(0) where G(k)= 1 - x + x*(2*k+1)/(1 - x + 2*x*(k+1)/G(k+1)); (continued fraction, 2-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 10 2012
G.f.: 1+x/U(0)  where U(k)=   1 - x + x*(k+1)/U(k+1) ; (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 06 2012
0 = a(n) * (a(n+2)) + a(n+1) * (-a(n+1) + 2*a(n+2) + a(n+3)) + a(n+2) * (-a(n+2)) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 27 2014
a(n) = -i*(BesselK[3/2,1]*BesselI[n+3/2,-1] - BesselI[3/2,-1]*BesselK[n+3/2,1]), n>=0 for unsigned version - _G. C. Greubel_ , Apr 19 2015

A000807.name: Quadratic invariants.
formula: a(0) = 1; a(n) = 2 * Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(2*n-1,2*k-1) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 27 2020

A000808.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000809.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000810.name: Expansion of e.g.f. (sin x + cos x)/cos 3x.
formula: a(n) ~ n!*2^(n+1)*3^(n+1/2)/Pi^(n+1) if n is even and a(n) ~ n!*2^(n+1)*3^n/Pi^(n+1) if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 25 2013
a(n) = (-1)^floor(n/2)*3^n*skp(n, 1/3), where skp(n,x) are the Swiss-Knife polynomials A153641. - _Peter Luschny_, Apr 19 2014

A000811.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000812.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000814.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000815.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000816.name: E.g.f.: Sum_{n >= 0} a(n) * x^(2*n) / (2*n)! = sin(x)^2 / cos(2*x).
formula: E.g.f.: sin(x)^2/cos(2x)=1/Q(0)-1/2;   Q(k)=1+1/(1-2*(x^2)/(2*(x^2)-(k+1)*(2k+1)/Q(k+1)));  (continued fraction). - Sergei N. Gladkovskii, Nov 18 2011
G.f.: (1/(G(0))-1)/2 where G(k) = 1 - 4*x*(k+1)^2/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 12 2013
G.f.: T(0)/2 -1/2, where T(k) = 1 - 4*x*(k+1)^2/( 4*x*(k+1)^2 - 1/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 25 2013

A000817.name: Number of switching networks under action of GL_n(Z_2).

A000818.name: Number of switching networks under action of GL_n(Z_2).

A000819.name: E.g.f.: cos(x)^2 / cos(2x) = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n) * x^(2n) / (2n)!.
formula: E.g.f.: cos(x)^2/cos(2x)=1/Q(0)+1/2;   Q(k)=1+1/(1-2*(x^2)/(2*(x^2)-(k+1)*(2k+1)/Q(k+1)));  (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 18 2011

A000820.name: Number of switching networks under action of AG_n(Z_2).

A000821.name: Number of switching networks under action of AG_n(Z_2).

A000823.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000824.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000825.name: Expansion of cos x (1 + sin x ) /cos 2x.

A000826.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000827.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000828.name: E.g.f. cos(x)/(cos(x) - sin(x)).
formula: a(n) = A000831(n)/2 for n>0. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 25 2010
a(n) = sum(evenp(n+k), k=1..n, (-1)^((n+k)/2)*sum(j=k..n, j!/n!*stirling2(n,j)*2^(n-j)*(-1)^(n+j-k)*binomial(j-1,k-1)), n>0. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 18 2010
a(n) = (-1)^((n^2-n)/2)*4^n*(E_{n}(1/2)+E_{n}(1))/2 for n >= 0, where E_{n}(x) is an Euler polynomial. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 25 2010
Let f(x) = 1+x^2 and define the effect of the operator D on a function g(x) by D(g(x)) = d/dx(f(x)*g(x)). Then for n >= 0, a(n+1) = D^n(1) evaluated at x = 1. - _Peter Bala_, Sep 02 2011
From _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 09 2011 - Dec 23 2013: (Start) Continued fractions:
a(0) = a(1) = 1; a(n) = 2 * Sum_{k=1..n-1} binomial(n-1,k) * a(k) * a(n-k-1). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Nov 21 2020

A000829.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000830.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000831.name: Expansion of e.g.f. (1 + tan(x))/(1 - tan(x)).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} (if even(n+k) ( (-1)^((n+k)/2)*Sum_{j=k..n} (j!*stirling2(n,j)*2^(n-j+1)*(-1)^(j)*binomial(j-1,k-1) ), n>0. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 19 2010
a(n) = 4^n*(E_{n}(1/2)+E_{n}(1))*(-1)^((n^2-n)/2) for n > 0, where E_{n}(x) is an Euler polynomial. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 24 2010
a(0) = 1; a(n) = 2 * Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n-2,k) * a(k) * a(n-k-1). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jun 11 2020

A000832.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000833.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000834.name: Expansion of exp(x)*(1 + tan(x))/(1 - tan(x)).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} binomial(n,i)*A000831(n-i). - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 19 2006
a(n) := -1 + Sum_{i=0...n} ((-1)^(i(i-1)/2) 4^i C(n,i)(E_{i}(1/2) + E_{i}(1))), where E_{n}(x) are Euler polynomials. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 25 2010
a(n) ~ n! * exp(Pi/4) * 2^(2*n+2) / Pi^(n+1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jul 02 2015

A000835.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000836.name: Number of switching networks (see Harrison reference for precise definition).

A000837.name: Number of partitions of n into relatively prime parts. Also aperiodic partitions.
formula: Möbius transform of A000041. - _Christian G. Bower_, Jun 11 2000
a(n) <= p(n) <= a(n+1), where p(n) is the number of partitions of n (A000041). - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jul 24 2020

A000838.name: Number of n-input 2-output switching networks under action of complementing group on the inputs and outputs.
formula: G.f.: A(x) = G(0) - 1 ; G(k) = 1 + (8*2^k -8 + 8^2^k*x*G(k+1))/2^(2^k+1) - Sergei N. Gladkovskii, Dec 02 2011 [edited by _Michael Somos_, Sep 07 2013]

A000888.name: a(n) = (2*n)!^2 / ((n+1)!*n!^3).
formula: Given G.f. A(x), y = x*A(x) satisfies y = y'' * (1 - 16*x) * x/4. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 11 2005
G.f.: 1 + 4*x/(G(0)-4*x) where G(k) = 4*x*(2*k+1)^2 + (k+1)*(k+2) - 4*x*(k+1)*(k+2)*(2*k+3)^2/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 30 2012
a(n) = C(n)*binomial(2*n,n) = Sum_{k=0..2*n} binomial(2*n,k)*C(k)*C(2*n-k) where C(k) are Catalan numbers (A000108), see Prodinger. - _Michel Marcus_, Nov 19 2019
