A000890.name: Number of switching networks with S(n) and C(2,2) acting on the domain and AG(2,3) acting on the range.

A000891.name: a(n) = (2*n)!*(2*n+1)! / (n! * (n+1)!)^2.
formula: G.f.: (1 - E(16*x)/(Pi/2))/(4*x) where E() is the elliptic integral of the second kind. [edited by _Olivier Gérard_, Feb 16 2011]
E.g.f.: Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^(2*n)/(2*n)! = BesselI(0, 2*x) * BesselI(1, 2*x) / x. - _Michael Somos_, Jun 22 2005
a(n) = A001263(2*n+1,n+1) = binomial(2*n+1,n+1)*binomial(2*n+1,n)/(2*n+1) (central members of odd numbered rows of Narayana triangle).
D-finite with recurrence (n+1)^2*a(n) - 4*(2*n-1)*(2*n+1)*a(n-1) = 0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Dec 03 2012

A000892.name: Number of switching networks with GL(n,2) acting on the domain and AG(2,2) acting on the range.

A000893.name: Number of switching networks with GL(n,2) acting on the domain and AG(3,2) acting on the range.

A000895.name: Number of switching networks with AG(n,2) acting on the domain and AG(2,2) acting on the range.

A000896.name: Number of switching networks with AG(n,2) acting on the domain and AG(3,2) acting on the range.

A000897.name: a(n) = (4*n)! / ((2*n)!*n!^2).
formula: E.g.f.: Sum_{k>=0} (-1)^k * a(k) * x^(4*k) / (4*k)! = BesselI(0, 2x) * BesselJ(0, 2x).
Sum_{k>=0} a(k) * x^(3k)/(3k)!^2 = f(x)*f(x*w)*f(x/w) where f(x) = BesselI(0, 2*sqrt(x)) and w = primitive 3rd root of unity. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 25 2007

In general, for (BesselI(b, 2x))*(BesselJ(b, 2x))=((x^(2*b))/((GAMMA(b+1))^2)*(1-(x^4)/(Q(0)+(x^4))); Q(k)=(k+1)*(k+b+1)*(2*k+b+1)*(2*k+b+2)-(x^4)+(x^4)*(k+1)*(k+b+1)*(2*k+b+1)*(2*k+b+2)/Q(k+1)) ; (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 24 2011
D-finite with recurrence 0 = a(n)*4*(4*n + 1)*(4*n + 3) - a(n+1)*(n + 1)^2 for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 12 2014

G.f.: 2*EllipticK(sqrt((sqrt(1-64*x)-1)/(2*sqrt(1-64*x))))/(Pi*(1-64*x)^(1/4)) where EllipticK is the complete elliptic integral of the first kind (in Maple's notation). - _Robert Israel_, Jul 12 2016

A000898.name: a(n) = 2*(a(n-1) + (n-1)*a(n-2)) for n >= 2 with a(0) = 1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{m=0..n} |A060821(n,m)| = H(n,-i)*i^n, with the Hermite polynomials H(n,x); i.e., these are row sums of the unsigned triangle A060821.
Binomial transform of A047974. - _Paul Barry_, May 09 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Stirling1(n, k)*2^k*Bell(k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Oct 01 2003
For asymptotics, see the Robinson paper. [This is disputed by _Yen-chi R. Lin_. See below, Sep 30 2013.]
E.g.f.: exp(x^2 + 2*x) = Q(0); Q(k) = 1 + (x^2 + 2*x)/(2*k + 1 - (x^2 + 2*x)*(2*k + 1)/((x^2 + 2*x) + (2*k + 2)/Q(k+1)))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 24 2011
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k) =  1 + 2*x*k - x - x/(1 - 2*x*(k + 1)/Q(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Mar 07 2013
a(n) = (2*n/e)^(n/2) * exp(sqrt(2*n)) / sqrt(2*e) * (1 + sqrt(2/n)/3 + O(n^(-1)). - _Yen-chi R. Lin_, Sep 30 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} 2^(n-k)*B(n, k), where B are the Bessel numbers A100861. - _Peter Luschny_, Jun 04 2021

A000899.name: Number of solutions to the rook problem on an n X n board having a certain symmetry group (see Robinson for details).
formula: For asymptotics see the Robinson paper.

A000900.name: Number of solutions to the rook problem on an n X n board having a certain symmetry group (see Robinson for details).
formula: For asymptotics see the Robinson paper.

A000901.name: Number of solutions to the rook problem on a 2n X 2n board having a certain symmetry group (see Robinson for details).
formula: For asymptotics see the Robinson paper.

A000902.name: Expansion of e.g.f. (1/2)*(exp(2*x + x^2) + 1).
formula: For asymptotics see the Robinson paper.
But the asymptotic formula in the Robinson paper is wrong (see A000898, discussion from Oct 01 2013). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 04 2014
a(n) = (i/2)^(1 - n)*KummerU((1 - n)/2, 3/2, -1)) for n>=1. - _Peter Luschny_, Nov 29 2017

A000903.name: Number of inequivalent ways of placing n nonattacking rooks on n X n board up to rotations and reflections of the board.
formula: If n>1 then a(n) = 1/8 * (F(n) + C(n) + 2 * R(n) + 2 * D(n)), where F(n) = A000142(n) [all solutions, i.e., factorials], C(n) = A037223(n) [central symmetric solutions], R(n) = A037224(n) [rotationally symmetric solutions] and D(n) = A000085(n) [symmetric solutions by reflection at a diagonal]. - _Matthias Engelhardt_, Apr 05 2000
For asymptotics see the Robinson paper.

A000904.name: a(n) = (n+1)*a(n-1) + (n+2)*a(n-2) + a(n-3); a(1)=0, a(2)=3, a(3)=13.
formula: G.f.: (1/E(0)-1+x-x^2)/x^2 where E(k)= (1+x)^2 + k*x - (k+1)*x*(1+x)^2/E(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 17 2012
(Note that (i) yields a(3)=13 and, for n>=4,
a(n-1) = (n+1)*a(n-2) + a(n-3) - 2*(-1)^n. Summing this with (i), we see that (i) defines A000904);
(iii)*  if n is even, then a(n) = Sum_{i=0..(n+2)/2)}A000179(2*i);
(iii)** if n is odd, then a(n) = Sum_{i=2..(n+1)/2} A000179(2*i+1).
Note that Lucas considered this sequence with other initials. His formulas (i) - (iii), which he proved on pp. 491-495 of his book [Lucas], we wrote for the current initials.
The other 5 formulas, including the explicit formula 5), are new and we give their proofs:
(iii)*,(iii)**. Formulas (iii)* and (iii)** are obtained by the direct summation of (iii) over even and odd values respectively, taking into account the initials.
(iv). To obtain (iv), write (iii) in the form
It is left to note that, by the definition,
(iv)*. In view of the first four initials 1,0,0,1 of A000271, we have
Sum_{i=0..n+2}(-1)^i*A000271(n-i+2) = Sum_{i=0..n-2}(-1)^i*A000271(n-i+2) and, by (iv), the last sum equals
(v). We use induction for n>=3. In case n=3 (v) gives 6-6*2+10-4=0 = a(1). Set n:=n+2.
Suppose for some (now n>=1) we have
Further we use (iv). In A259212 we proved an explicit formula for A000271(n-1) such that we have
Now, by (iv) and (*) with changing summing j=i+1, we have
Since binomial(n,-1)=0, then in the second sum the summing could begin with j=0.
Thus this expression formally is obtained from (*) by replacing n with n+1.
a(n) ~ n! * n^2 / exp(2). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jul 04 2015

A000907.name: Second order reciprocal Stirling number (Fekete) [[2n+2, n]]. The number of n-orbit permutations of a (2n+2)-set with at least 2 elements in each orbit. Also known as associated Stirling numbers of the first kind (e.g., Comtet).
formula: [[2n+2, n]] = sum((-1)^i*binomial(2n+2, 2n+2-i)[2n+2-i, n-i] where [n, k] is the unsigned Stirling number of the first kind. - Barbara Haas Margolius (margolius(AT)math.csuohio.edu), Dec 14 2000

A000908.name: Atom-rooted polyenoids with n edges with symmetry class C_s.
formula: a(n) = A003446(n) - u((n-3)/6) - (u(n/3) + u((n-3)/6))/2 - (u(n/2) + (u((n+1)/2) - u((n-3)/6))) for n > 3 where u(n) = binomial(2*n, n)/(n+1) if n is an integer and 0 otherwise. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Oct 05 2015

A000911.name: a(n) = (2n+3)! /( n! * (n+1)! ).
formula: G.f.: 6*(1+10*x/( G(0)- 10*x)), where G(k)= 2*x*(2*k+5) + k + 1 - 2*x*(k+1)*(2*k+7)/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 14 2013

A000912.name: Expansion of (sqrt(1-4x^2) - sqrt(1-4x))/(2x).
formula: a(n) = C(n) if n is even and a(n) = C(n) -C((n-1)/2) if n is odd, where C(n) = binomial(2n, n)/(n+1) are the Catalan numbers (A000108). a(n) = 2*A000150(n) for n > 0. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Dec 19 2004

A000913.name: Number of bond-rooted polyenoids with n edges.
formula: a(n) = (1/4)*c(n+2) - (1/2)*c(n+1) - (3/4)*c((n+1)/2) + (1/2)*c((n-1)/4), where c(n) = binomial(2n, n)/(n+1) are the Catalan numbers for n a nonnegative integer and 0 otherwise.

A000914.name: Stirling numbers of the first kind: s(n+2, n).
formula: a(n) = a(n-1) + (n+1)*binomial(n+1,2) for n >= 1. - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Sep 21 2015
a(n) = A001296(-2-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 04 2017

A000915.name: Stirling numbers of first kind s(n+4, n).
formula: Stirling1(n+1, n-3) = Sum_{L=1..n} (Sum_{k=L+1..n} (Sum_{j=k+1..n} (Sum_{i=j+1..n} i*j*k*L))), cf. A001298. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 31 2005
a(n) = (f(n+3, 4)/8!)*Sum_{m=0..min(4, n-1)} A112486(4,m)*f(8, 4-m)*f(n-1, m), with the falling factorials f(n, m):=n*(n-1)*...*(n-(m-1)).
a(n) = A001298(-4-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 04 2017

A000916.name: a(2n) = n+2, a(2n-1) = smallest number requiring n+2 letters in English.

A000918.name: a(n) = 2^n - 2.
formula: G.f.: 1/(1 - 2*x) - 2/(1 - x), e.g.f.: (e^x - 1)^2 - 1. - Dan Fux (dan.fux(AT)OpenGaia.com or danfux(AT)OpenGaia.com), Apr 07 2001
For n >= 1, a(n) = A008970(n + 1, 2). - _Philippe Deléham_, Feb 21 2004
G.f.: (3*x - 1)/((2*x - 1)*(x - 1)). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation for the sequence without the leading -1
a(n) = A164874(n - 1, n - 1) for n > 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 29 2009
G.f.: U(0) -1 , where U(k) = 1 + x/(2^k + 2^k/(x - 1 - x^2*2^(k + 1)/(x*2^(k + 1) - (k + 1)/U(k + 1) ))); (continued fraction, 3rd kind, 4-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 01 2012
a(n+1) = sum of row n in triangle A051601. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 05 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n-1} binomial(n, k) for n > 0. - _Dan McCandless_, Nov 14 2015

a(n+1) = 2*(n + Sum_{j=1..n-1} (n-j)*2^(j-1)), n >= 1. This is the number of the rationals k/2, k = 1..2*n for n >= 1 and (2*k+1)/2^j for j = 2..n, n >= 2, and 2*k+1 < n-(j-1). See the example for n = 3 below. Motivated by the proposal A287012 by _Mark Rickert_. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jun 14 2017

A000919.name: a(n) = 4^n - C(4,3)*3^n + C(4,2)*2^n - C(4,1).
formula: a(n) = 4^n - binomial(4,3)*3^n + binomial(4,2)*2^n - binomial(4,1) = 24*A000453(n). - _David Wasserman_, Jun 06 2007
a(n) = k!*S2(n,k), where k=4 is the number of colors and S2 is the Stirling subset number. - _Robert A. Russell_, Sep 25 2018

A000920.name: Differences of 0: 6!*Stirling2(n,6).
formula: G.f.: 720*x^6/((x-1)*(6*x-1)*(4*x-1)*(3*x-1)*(2*x-1)*(5*x-1)). [Maksym Voznyy (voznyy(AT)mail.ru), Jul 26 2009; checked and corrected by _R. J. Mathar_, Sep 16 2009]

A000921.name: Primes p of the form 3k+1 such that Sum_{x=1..p} cos(2*Pi*x^3/p) >  sqrt(p).

A000922.name: Primes p of the form 3k+1 such that -sqrt(p) < sum_{x=1..p} cos(2*Pi*x^3/p) < sqrt(p).

A000923.name: Primes p of the form 3k+1 such that sum_{x=1..p} cos(2*Pi*x^3/p) < -sqrt(p).

A000924.name: Class number of Q(sqrt(-n)), n squarefree.

A000925.name: Number of ordered ways of writing n as a sum of 2 squares of nonnegative integers.
formula: Coefficient of q^k in (1/4)*(1 + theta_3(0, q))^2.

A000926.name: Euler's "numerus idoneus" (or "numeri idonei", or idoneal, or suitable, or convenient numbers).

A000927.name: "First factor" (or relative class number) h- for cyclotomic field Q( exp(2 Pi / prime(n)) ).
formula: For n>2, a(n) equals absolute value of determinant of the matrix with entries floor(i*j/p)-floor((i-1)*j/p), 3 <= i,j <= (p-1)/2, where p = prime(n) = A000040(n). - _Max Alekseyev_, Oct 31 2012

A000928.name: Irregular primes: primes p such that at least one of the numerators of the Bernoulli numbers B_2, B_4, ..., B_{p-3} (A000367) is divisible by p.

A000929.name: Dimension of n-th degree part of Steenrod algebra.
formula: G.f.: 1/Product_{i>=1} (1 - x^(2^i-1)). - _Simon Plouffe_ (corrected by _Joerg Arndt_, Dec 28 2012)
a(n) = p(n,1) with p(n,k) = if k <= n then p(n-k,k) + p(n,2*k+1), otherwise 0^n. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 18 2009
G.f.: Sum_{i>=0} x^(2^i-1) / Product_{j=1..i} (1 - x^(2^j-1)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jun 05 2017

A000930.name: Narayana's cows sequence: a(0) = a(1) = a(2) = 1; thereafter a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-3).
formula: a(n) = floor(d*c^n + 1/2) where c is the real root of x^3-x^2-1 and d is the real root of 31*x^3-31*x^2+9*x-1 (c = 1.465571... = A092526 and d = 0.611491991950812...). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 30 2002
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(floor((n+2k-2)/3), k). - _Paul Barry_, Jul 06 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(k, floor((n-k)/2))(1+(-1)^(n-k))/2. - _Paul Barry_, Jan 12 2006
a(n) = term (1,1) in matrix [1,1,0; 0,0,1; 1,0,0]^n. - _Alois P. Heinz_, Jun 20 2008
Logarithmic derivative equals A001609. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 08 2009
a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2) - a(n-5) for n>4. - _Paul Weisenhorn_, Oct 28 2011
G.f.: 1/(G(0)-x) where G(k) = 1 - x^2/(1 - x^2/(x^2 - 1/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 16 2012
G.f.: 1 + x/(G(0)-x) where G(k) = 1 - x^2*(2*k^2 + 3*k +2) + x^2*(k+1)^2*(1 - x^2*(k^2 + 3*k +2))/G(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 27 2012
G.f.: Q(0)/2, where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(4*k+1 + x^2)/( x*(4*k+3 + x^2) + 1/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 08 2013

A000931.name: Padovan sequence (or Padovan numbers): a(n) = a(n-2) + a(n-3) with a(0) = 1, a(1) = a(2) = 0.
formula: a(n) is asymptotic to r^n / (2*r+3) where r = 1.3247179572447... = A060006, the real root of x^3 = x + 1. - _Philippe Deléham_, Jan 13 2004
a(n) = central and lower right terms in the (n-3)-th power of the 3 X 3 matrix M = [0 1 0 / 0 0 1 / 1 1 0]. E.g., a(13) = 7. M^10 = [3 5 4 / 4 7 5 / 5 9 7]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Feb 01 2004
a(n+4) = Sum_{k=0..floor((n-1)/2)} binomial(floor((n+k-2)/3), k). - _Paul Barry_, Jul 06 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} binomial(k, n-2k). - _Paul Barry_, Sep 17 2004
a(n+3) is diagonal sum of A026729 (as a number triangle), with formula a(n+3) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} Sum_{i=0..n-k} (-1)^(n-k+i)*binomial(n-k, i)*binomial(i+k, i-k). - _Paul Barry_, Sep 23 2004
a(n+3) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} binomial((n-k)/2, k)(1+(-1)^(n-k))/2. - _Paul Barry_, Sep 09 2005
The sequence 1/(1-x^2-x^3) (a(n+3)) is given by the diagonal sums of the Riordan array (1/(1-x^3), x/(1-x^3)). The row sums are A000930. - _Paul Barry_, Feb 25 2005
a(n) = A023434(n-7) + 1 for n >= 7. - _David Callan_, Jul 14 2006

a(n+5) corresponds to the diagonal sums of A030528. The binomial transform of a(n+5) is A052921. a(n+5) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} Sum_{k=0..n} (-1)^(n-k+i)binomial(n-k, i)binomial(i+k+1, 2k+1). - _Paul Barry_, Jun 21 2004
a(n) = (r^n)/(2r+3) + (s^n)/(2s+3) + (t^n)/(2t+3) where r, s, t are the three roots of x^3-x-1. - Keith Schneider (schneidk(AT)email.unc.edu), Sep 07 2007
a(n) = -k*a(n-1) + a(n-2) + (k+1)a(n-2) + k*a(n-4), n > 3, for any value of k. - _Gary Detlefs_, Sep 13 2010
a(n+3) = Sum_{k=0..floor((n+1)/2)} binomial((n+k)/3,k), where binomial((n+k)/3,k)=0 for noninteger (n+k)/3. - _Nikita Gogin_, Dec 07 2012
a(n) = A182097(n-3) for n > 2. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Mar 14 2014
a(n) = the k-th difference of a(n+5k) - a(n+5k-1), k>=1. For example, a(10)=3 => a(15)-a(14) => 2nd difference of a(20)-a(19) => 3rd difference of a(25)-a(24)... - _Bob Selcoe_, Mar 18 2014

Construct the power matrix T(n,j) = [A^*j]*[S^*(j-1)] where A=(0,0,1,0,1,0,1,...) and S=(0,1,0,0,...) or A063524. [* is convolution operation] Define S^*0=I with I=(1,0,0,...). Then a(n) = Sum_{j=1...n} T(n,j). - _David Neil McGrath_, Dec 19 2014
If x=a(n), y=a(n+1), z=a(n+2), then x^3 + 2*y*x^2 - z^2*x - 3*y*z*x + y^2*x + y^3 - y^2*z + z^3 = 1. - _Alexander Samokrutov_, Jul 20 2015
For the sequence shifted by 6 terms, a(n) = Sum( binomial(k+1,3*k-n), k=ceiling(n/3)..ceiling(n/2)) [Doslic-Zubac]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 23 2017

A000932.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + n*a(n-2); a(0) = a(1) = 1.
formula: If offset 1, then e.g.f. A(x) satisfies: F(A(x)) = 1 + x, where F(x) equals the e.g.f. of A173895 and satisfies: F'(x) = 1/(1 + x*F(x)). (End)

A000933.name: Genus of complete graph on n nodes.
formula: Euler transform of length 10 sequence [ 1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 0, -1]. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 24 2005

A000934.name: Chromatic number (or Heawood number) Chi(n) of surface of genus n.

A000935.name: Number of free planar polyenoids with 2n nodes and symmetry point group C_{2h}.

A000936.name: Number of free planar polyenoids with n nodes and symmetry point group C_{2v}.

A000937.name: Length of longest simple cycle without chords in the n-dimensional hypercube graph. Also called n-coil or closed n-snake-in-the-box problem.

A000938.name: Number of collinear point-triples in an n X n grid.
formula: a(n) = 2*Sum(Sum((n - k + 1)*(n - m + 1)*gcd(k - 1, m - 1), k, 2, n), m, 2, n) - n^2(n^2 - 1)/6. - _Ignacio Larrosa Cañestro_, May 23 2010
a(n) = binomial(n^2, 3) - A045996(n). - _Ignacio Larrosa Cañestro_, May 23 2010

A000940.name: Number of n-gons with n vertices.

A000941.name: Number of free planar polyenoids with n nodes and symmetry point group C_s.

A000942.name: Number of free planar polyenoids with n nodes.

A000943.name: Number of combinatorial types of simplicial n-dimensional polytopes with n+3 nodes.

A000944.name: Number of polyhedra (or 3-connected simple planar graphs) with n nodes.

A000945.name: Euclid-Mullin sequence: a(1) = 2, a(n+1) is smallest prime factor of 1 + Product_{k=1..n} a(k).

A000946.name: Euclid-Mullin sequence: a(1) = 2, a(n+1) is largest prime factor of Product_{k=1..n} a(k) + 1.

A000947.name: Number of free nonplanar polyenoids with n nodes and symmetry point group C_{2v}.

A000948.name: Number of free nonplanar polyenoids with n nodes and symmetry point group C_s.

A000949.name: Number of forests with n nodes and height at most 2.

A000950.name: Number of forests with n nodes and height at most 3.

A000951.name: Number of forests with n nodes and height at most 4.

A000952.name: Numbers n == 2 (mod 4) that are the orders of conference matrices.

A000953.name: Number of free nonplanar polyenoids with n nodes.

A000954.name: Conjecturally largest even integer which is an unordered sum of two primes in exactly n ways.

A000957.name: Fine's sequence (or Fine numbers): number of relations of valence >= 1 on an n-set; also number of ordered rooted trees with n edges having root of even degree.
formula: G.f.: (1-sqrt(1-4*x))/(3-sqrt(1-4*x)) (compare g.f. for Catalan numbers, A000108). - _Emeric Deutsch_
a(n) = 3*Sum_{j=0..floor((n-1)/2)} binomial(2n-2j-2, n-1) - binomial(2n, n) for n>0. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 28 2004
Hankel determinant transform is 1-n. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 17 2006
a(n+1) has g.f. 1/(1-0*x-x^2/(1-2*x-x^2/(1-2*x-x^2/(1-2*x-x^2/(..... (continued fraction). - _Paul Barry_, Dec 02 2008
G.f.: x*c(x)/(1+x*c(x)), c(x) the g.f. of A000108;

Let A be the Toeplitz matrix of order n defined by: A[i,i-1] = -1, A[i,j] = Catalan(j-i), (i<=j), and A[i,j] = 0, otherwise. Then, for n>=1, a(n+1) = (-1)^n*charpoly(A,1). - _Milan Janjic_, Jul 08 2010
a(n) = the upper left term in M^n, n>0; where M = the infinite square production matrix:
D-finite with recurrence: 2*n*a(n) +(12-7*n)*a(n-1) +2*(3-2*n)*a(n-2)=0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Nov 15 2011
a(n) = sum(sum(2^(s-2n-2k)*(n/n+2k)binomial(n+2k, k)*binomial(s-n-1, s-2n-2k), (k=0, ..., floor((s-2n)/2)), (n=1, ..., s) with s>=2. - _José Luis Ramírez Ramírez_, Mar 22 2012
G.f. A(x) satisfies x*A'(x)/A(x) = x + 2*x^3 + 6*x^4 + 22*x^5 + ..., the o.g.f. for A072547. - _Peter Bala_, Oct 01 2015

O.g.f. A(x) satisfies 1 + A(x) =  (1 + 3*Sum_{n >= 1} Catalan(n)*x^n)/(1 + 2*Sum_{n >= 1} Catalan(n)*x^n) = (1 + 2*Sum_{n >= 1} binomial(2*n,n)*x^n )/(1 + 3/2*Sum_{n >= 1} binomial(2*n,n)*x^n). - _Peter Bala_, Sep 01 2016
a(n) = Sum_{i=2..n-1} C(n-i-1)*(a(i)+a(i-1)), a(0)=0, a(1)=1, where C(n) = A000108(n). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Apr  23 2020

A000958.name: Number of ordered rooted trees with n edges having root of odd degree.
formula: G.f.: z*C/(1-z^2*C^2), where C=(1-sqrt(1-4*z))/(2*z) is the Catalan function. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 02 2007
a(n) = sum of top row terms in M^(n-1), where M = the following infinite square production matrix:
a(n) = Catalan(n-1)*h(n-1) for n>=2 where h(n) = hypergeom([1,3/2,-n/2,(1-n)/2],[1/2,-n,-n+1/2], 1). - _Peter Luschny_, Apr 25 2016

A000959.name: Lucky numbers.
formula: Start with the natural numbers. Delete every 2nd number, leaving 1 3 5 7 ...; the 2nd number remaining is 3, so delete every 3rd number, leaving 1 3 7 9 13 15 ...; now delete every 7th number, leaving 1 3 7 9 13 ...; now delete every 9th number; etc.
a(n) = A258207(n,n). [Where A258207 is a square array constructed from the numbers remaining after each step described above.] - _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 06 2015
A145649(a(n)) = 1; complement of A050505. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 15 2008

A000960.name: Flavius Josephus's sieve: Start with the natural numbers; at the k-th sieving step, remove every (k+1)-st term of the sequence remaining after the (k-1)-st sieving step; iterate.
formula: Let F(n) = number of terms <= n. Andersson, improving results of Brun, shows that F(n) = 2 sqrt(n/Pi) + O(n^(1/6)). Hence a(n) grows like Pi*n^2 / 4.

To get n-th term, start with n and successively round up to next 2 multiples of n-1, n-2, ..., 1 (compare to Mancala sequence A002491). E.g.: to get 11th term: 11->30->45->56->63->72->80->84->87->90->91; i.e., start with 11, successively round up to next 2 multiples of 10, 9, .., 1. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 10 2005

As in Paul D. Hanna's formula, start with n^2 and successively move down to the highest multiple of n-1, n-2, etc., smaller than your current number: 121 120 117 112 105 102 100 96 93 92 91, so a(11) = 91, from moving down to multiples of 10, 9, ..., 1. - _Joshua Zucker_, May 20 2006

Or, similarly for n = 5, begin with 25, down to a multiple of 4 = 24, down to a multiple of 3 = 21, then to a multiple of 2 = 20 and finally to a multiple of 1 = 19, so a(5) = 19. - _Joshua Zucker_, May 20 2006
This formula arises in A119446; the leading term of row k of that triangle = a(prime(k)/k) from this sequence. - _Joshua Zucker_, May 20 2006
a(n) = 2*A073359(n-1) + 1, cf. link to posts on the SeqFan list. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 23 2016
a(n) = 1 + A278484(n-1). - _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 23 2016, after _David W. Wilson_'s posting on SeqFan list Nov 22 2016

A000961.name: Powers of primes. Alternatively, 1 and the prime powers (p^k, p prime, k >= 1).
formula: Panaitopol (2001) gives many properties, inequalities and asymptotics (including a(n) ~ pi(n)). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 31 2014

m=a(n) for some n <=> lcm(1,...,m-1) < lcm(1,...,m), where lcm(1...0):=0 as to include a(1)=1. a(n+1)=a(n)+1 <=> a(n+1)=A019434(k) or a(n)=A000668(k) for some k (by Catalan's conjecture), except for n=1 and n=7. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 18 2007, Apr 18 2010
A008480(a(n)) = 1 for all n >= 1. - _Alois P. Heinz_, May 26 2018

A000962.name: The convergent sequence A_n for the ternary continued fraction (3,1;2,2) of period 2.

A000963.name: The convergent sequence B_n for the ternary continued fraction (3,1;2,2) of period 2.

A000964.name: The convergent sequence C_n for the ternary continued fraction (3,1;2,2) of period 2.

A000965.name: Numerators of expansion of e.g.f. sinh(x) / sin(x) (even powers only).
formula: Numerator of ( (2n)! times coefficient of x^(2n) in sinh x / sin x ).

A000966.name: n! never ends in this many 0's.
formula: The simplest way to obtain this sequence is by constructing a power series A(x) = Sum_{k >= 1} x^a(k) whose exponents give the terms of the sequence. Define e(n) = (5^n-1)/4, f(n) = (1-x^(e(n)-1))/(1-x^e(n-1)), t(n) = x^(e(n)-6).

Now use the recurrence A[2] = 1 and for n >= 3, A[n] = f(n)*A[n-1]+t(n); then A = limit_{n->infinity} x^5*A[n]. This follows easily from the explicit formula for A027868(n). Here is the beginning of A: x^5 + x^11 + x^17 + x^23 + x^29 + x^30 + x^36 + x^42 + x^48 + ... - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 02 2007

Formula from C. W. Trigg (see the Moser reference): All terms can be described as follows: for k = 1, 2, 3, ..., the number 6k-1 + floor(k/5) + floor(k/5^2) + floor(k/5^3) + ... is a term together with A112765(k) preceding numbers. [corrected and simplified by _Gerald Hillier_ and _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, Sep 13 2017]

A000967.name: Sum of Fermat coefficients.
formula: Following Piza's definition for the Fermat coefficients: (n:c)=binomial(2n-c, c-1)/c, a(n)= Round( sum_ {c=1..n} (n:c) ). - Pab Ter (pabrlos2(AT)yahoo.com), Oct 13 2005

A000968.name: Sum of odd Fermat coefficients rounded to nearest integer.
formula: Following Piza's definition for the Fermat coefficients: (n:c)=binomial(2n-c, c-1)/c, a(n)= Round( sum_{c<=n & c odd} (n:c) ). - Pab Ter (pabrlos2(AT)yahoo.com), Oct 13 2005

A000969.name: Expansion of (1+x+2*x^2)/((1-x)^2*(1-x^3)).
formula: a(n) = floor( (2*n+3)*(n+1)/3 ). Or, a(n) = (2*n+3)*(n+1)/3 but subtract 1/3 if n == 1 mod 3. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 05 2010.
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} floor(4*i/3). - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Apr 21 2012

A000973.name: Fermat coefficients.
formula: G(k) = (k+1)*(2*k+3) + x*(k+5)*(2*k+9) - x*(k+1)*(k+6)*(2*k+3)*(2*k+11)/G(k+1); (continued fraction Euler's 1st kind, 1-step ). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 15 2012

A000974.name: Conjecturally the number of even integers the sum of two primes in exactly n ways.

A000975.name: a(2n) = 2*a(2n-1), a(2n+1) = 2*a(2n)+1 (also a(n) is the n-th number without consecutive equal binary digits).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i = 0..n} A001045(i), partial sums of A001045. - _Bill Blewett_
(-1)^(n+1)*a(n) = Sum_{i = 0..n} Sum_{k = 1..i} k!*k* Stirling2(i, k)*(-1)^(k-1) = (1/3)*(-2)^(n+1)-(1/6)(3*(-1)^(n+1)-1). - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Dec 22 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} 2^(n-k-1)*(1-(-1)^k), row sums of A130125. - _Paul Barry_, Jul 28 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} binomial(k, n-k+1)2^(n-k); a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..floor(n/2)} binomial(n-k, k+1)2^k. - _Paul Barry_, Oct 07 2004
Convolution of "Number of fixed points in all 231-avoiding involutions in S_n." (A059570) with "1-n" (A024000), treating the result as if offset was 0. - _Graeme McRae_, Jul 12 2006
Starting (1, 2, 5, 10, 21, 42, ...), these are the row sums of triangle A135228. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 23 2007
If we define f(m,j,x) = Sum_{k=j..m} binomial(m,k)*stirling2(k,j)*x^(m-k) then a(n-3) = (-1)^(n-1)*f(n,3,-2), (n >= 3). - _Milan Janjic_, Apr 26 2009
a(n) = binary XOR of 2^k-1 for k=0..n. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 05 2011
Starting with "1" = triangle A059260 * [1, 2, 2, 2, ...] as a vector. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Mar 06 2012
floor(a(n+2)*3/5) = A077854(n), for n >= 0. - _Armands Strazds_, Sep 21 2014
Binary: a(n) = (a(n-1) shift left 1) + (a(n-1)) NOR (...11110). - _Paul Toms_, Mar 18 2015
Binary: for n > 1, a(n) = 2*a(n-1) OR a(n-2). - _Stanislav Sykora_, Nov 12 2015
a(n) = A266613(n) - 20*2^(n-5), for n > 2. - _Andres Cicuttin_, Mar 31 2016
a(n) = -(2^n)*a(-n) for even n; a(n) = -(2^(n+1))*a(-n) + 1 for odd n.

A000976.name: Period of 1 / n! in base 10.
formula: a(n) = k where k is the smallest integer>=1 such that 10^k=1 mod n!/(2^A011371(n)*5^floor(n/5)) and A011371 is the highest power of 2 dividing n!. - C. Ronaldo (aga_new_ac(AT)hotmail.com), Dec 16 2004
a(n) = order(10, n!/(2^s*5^t)) where 2^s is largest power of 2 dividing n! and 5^t is largest power of 5 dividing n! - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 29 2011

A000977.name: Numbers that are divisible by at least three different primes.
formula: a(n) = n + O(n log log n / log n). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 19 2011 A001221(a(n)) > 2. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 03 2013
A033992 UNION A033993 UNION A051270 UNION A074969 UNION A176655 UNION ... - _R. J. Mathar_, Dec 05 2016

A000978.name: Wagstaff numbers: numbers k such that (2^k + 1)/3 is prime.
formula: a(n) = A107036(n) for n>1. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Feb 10 2007

A000980.name: Number of ways of writing 0 as Sum_{k=-n..n} e(k)*k, where e(k) is 0 or 1.
formula: a(n) = sum_i A067059(2n+1-i, i) = 2+2*sum_j A047997(n, j); i.e., sum of alternate antidiagonals of A067059 and two more than twice row sums of A047997. - _Henry Bottomley_, Aug 11 2002
Coefficient of x^(n*(n+1)/2) in 2*prod(k=1..n,(1+x^k)^2). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Oct 03 2011

A000981.name: Numbers beginning with letter 'n' in English.

A000982.name: a(n) = ceiling(n^2/2).
formula: G.f.: (x + x^2 + x^3 + x^4)/((1 - x)*(1 - x^2)^2), not reduced. - _Len Smiley_
Starting with offset 1, = row sums of triangle A134444. Also, with offset 1, = binomial transform of [1, 1, 2, -2, 4, -8, 16, -32, ...]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 25 2007
a(n) = n^2 - floor(n^2/2). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Jun 14 2013
a(n) = a(-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, May 05 2015
a(n) is also the number of independent entries in a centrosymmetric n X n matrix: M(i, j) = M(n-i+1, n-j+1). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Oct 12 2015
For n > 1, a(n+1)/a(n) = 3 - A081352(n-2)/a(n). - _Miko Labalan_, Mar 26 2016
E.g.f.: (1/2)*(x*(1 + x)*cosh(x) + (1 + x + x^2)*sinh(x)). - _Stefano Spezia_, Feb 03 2020
a(n) = binomial(n+1,2) - floor(n/2). - _César Eliud Lozada_, Oct 25 2020

A000983.name: Size of minimal binary covering code of length n and covering radius 1.

A000984.name: Central binomial coefficients: binomial(2*n,n) = (2*n)!/(n!)^2.
formula: Using Stirling's formula in A000142 it is easy to get the asymptotic expression a(n) ~ 4^n / sqrt(Pi * n). - Dan Fux (dan.fux(AT)OpenGaia.com or danfux(AT)OpenGaia.com), Apr 07 2001

Integral representation as n-th moment of a positive function on the interval[0, 4], in Maple notation: a(n) =  Integral_{x=0..4}(x^n*((x*(4-x))^(-1/2))/Pi), n=0, 1, ... This representation is unique. - _Karol A. Penson_, Sep 17 2001
E.g.f.: exp(2*x)*I_0(2x), where I_0 is Bessel function. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 08 2002
E.g.f.: I_0(2*x) = Sum a(n)*x^(2*n)/(2*n)!, where I_0 is Bessel function. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 09 2002
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, k)^2. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jan 31 2003
Determinant of n X n matrix M(i, j) = binomial(n+i, j). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 28 2003

Given m = C(2*n, n), let f be the inverse function, so that f(m) = n. Letting q denote -log(log(16)/(m^2*Pi)), we have f(m) = ceiling( (q + log(q)) / log(16) ). - David W. Cantrell (DWCantrell(AT)sigmaxi.net), Oct 30 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(2n+1, k)*sin((2n-2k+1)*Pi/2). - _Paul Barry_, Nov 02 2004
a(n) = C(2n, n-1) + C(n) = A001791(n) + A000108(n). - _Lekraj Beedassy_, Aug 02 2005
G.f.: c(x)^2/(2*c(x)-c(x)^2) where c(x) is the g.f. of A000108. - _Paul Barry_, Feb 03 2006
Row sums of triangle A135091. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 18 2007
If n>=3 is prime, then a(n)==2(mod 2*n). - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Sep 05 2010
Let A(x) be the g.f. and B(x) = A(-x), then B(x) = sqrt(1-4*x*B(x)^2). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Jan 16 2011
a(n) = upper left term in M^n, M = the infinite square production matrix:
G.f.: 1 + 2*x/(U(0)-2*x) where U(k) = 2*(2*k+1)*x + (k+1) - 2*(k+1)*(2*k+3)*x/U(k+1); (continued fraction, Euler's 1st kind, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 28 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n,k)^2*H(k)/(2*H(n)-H(2*n)), n>0, where H(n) is the n-th harmonic number. - _Gary Detlefs_, Mar 19 2013
G.f.: Q(0)*(1-4*x), where Q(k)= 1 + 4*(2*k+1)*x/( 1 - 1/(1 + 2*(k+1)/Q(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 11 2013
G.f.: G(0)/2, where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - 2*x*(2*k+1)/(2*x*(2*k+1) + (k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 24 2013
E.g.f.: E(0)/2, where E(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - 2*x/(2*x + (k+1)^2/(2*k+1)/E(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 01 2013
Special values of Jacobi polynomials, in Maple notation: a(n) = 4^n*JacobiP(n,0,-1/2-n,-1). - _Karol A. Penson_, Jul 27 2013
Sum_{n>=0} a(n)/n! = A234846. - _Richard R. Forberg_, Feb 10 2014
0 =  a(n)*(16*a(n+1) - 6*a(n+2)) + a(n+1)*(-2*a(n+1) + a(n+2)) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 17 2014
G.f.: Sum_{n>=0} x^n/(1-x)^(2*n+1) * Sum_{k=0..n} C(n,k)^2 * x^k. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 08 2014

A(-x) = 1/x * series reversion( x*(2*x + sqrt(1 + 4*x^2)) ). Compare with the o.g.f. B(x) of A098616, which satisfies B(-x) = 1/x * series reversion( x*(2*x + sqrt(1 - 4*x^2) ). See also A214377. - _Peter Bala_, Oct 19 2015
Sum_{n>=0} (-1)^n/a(n) = 4*(5 - sqrt(5)*log(phi))/25 = 0.6278364236143983844442267..., where phi is the golden ratio. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jul 04 2016
This sequence occurs as the closed-form expression for several binomial sums:
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..2*n} (-1)^k*binomial(2*n,k)*binomial(x + k,n)*binomial(y + k,n) = Sum_{k = 0..2*n} (-1)^k*binomial(2*n,k)*binomial(x - k,n)*binomial(y - k,n) for arbitrary x and y.

For m = 3,4,5,... both Sum_{k = 0..m*n} (-1)^k*binomial(m*n,k)*binomial(x + k,n)*binomial(y + k,n) and Sum_{k = 0..m*n} (-1)^k*binomial(m*n,k)*binomial(x - k,n)*binomial(y - k,n) appear to equal Kronecker's delta(n,0).
a(n) = (-1)^n*Sum_{k = 0..2*n} (-1)^k*binomial(2*n,k)*binomial(x + k,n)*binomial(y - k,n) for arbitrary x and y.
For m = 3,4,5,... Sum_{k = 0..m*n} (-1)^k*binomial(m*n,k)*binomial(x + k,n)*binomial(y - k,n) appears to equal Kronecker's delta(n,0).
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..2n} (-1)^k*binomial(2*n,k)*binomial(3*n - k,n)^2 = Sum_{k = 0..2*n} (-1)^k*binomial(2*n,k)* binomial(n + k,n)^2. (Gould, Vol. 7, 5.23).
Sum_{k>=0} a(k)/(p/q)^k = sqrt(p/(p-4q)) for q in N, p in Z/{-4q< (some p) <-2}.
Boas-Buck recurrence: a(n) = (2/n)*Sum_{k=0..n-1} 4^(n-k-1)*a(k), n >= 1, a(0) = 1. Proof from a(n) = A046521(n, 0). See a comment there. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Aug 10 2017
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} (-1)^(n-k) * binomial(2*n+1, k) for n in N. - _Rene Adad_, Sep 30 2017

A000985.name: Number of n X n symmetric matrices with nonnegative entries and all row sums 2.

A000986.name: Number of n X n symmetric matrices with (0,1) entries and all row sums 2.
formula: a(n) ~ n^n * exp(sqrt(2*n)-n-3/2) / sqrt(2) * (1 + 43/(24*sqrt(2*n))). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 13 2014

A000987.name: Number of stochastic matrices of integers.

A000988.name: Number of one-sided polyominoes with n cells.

A000989.name: 3-adic valuation of binomial(2*n, n): largest k such that 3^k divides binomial(2*n, n).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k>=0} floor(2*n/3^k) - 2*Sum_{k>=0} floor(n/3^k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 26 2003

A000990.name: Number of plane partitions of n with at most two rows.
formula: G.f.: exp( Sum_{n>=1} ((1+x^n)/(1-x^n))*x^n/n ). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Apr 22 2010
For n>=1, a(n) = A000712(n) - A000712(n-1). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 28 2015
a(n) ~ Pi * exp(2*Pi*sqrt(n/3)) / (4 * 3^(5/4) * n^(7/4)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 28 2015

A000992.name: "Half-Catalan numbers": a(n) = Sum_{k=1..floor(n/2)} a(k)*a(n-k) with a(1) = 1.

A000993.name: Number of distinct quadratic residues mod 10^n; also number of distinct n-digit endings of base-10 squares.

A000994.name: Shifts 2 places left under binomial transform.
formula: Since this satisfies a recurrence similar to that of the Bell numbers (A000110), the asymptotic behavior is presumably just as complicated - see A000110 for details.
O.g.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} x^(2*n)*(1-n*x)/Product_{k=0..n} (1-k*x)^2. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 02 2006
G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = 1 + x^2 * A(x/(1 - x)) / (1 - x). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 09 2020

A000995.name: Shifts left two terms under the binomial transform.
formula: Since this satisfies a recurrence similar to that of the Bell numbers (A000110), the asymptotic behavior is presumably just as complicated - see A000110 for details.
O.g.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} x^(2*n+1)/Product_{k=0..n} (1-k*x)^2. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 28 2006
G.f.: (1+2*x^2*c(x)^2)/(1+x^2*c(x^2)), c(x) the g.f. of A000108. - _Paul Barry_, Oct 06 2007. This g.f. is incorrect. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 14 2014
E.g.f: -2 * exp(x) *( BesselI_0(2) * BesselK_0(2*exp(x/2)) - BesselK_0(2) * 0F1([], [1], exp(x)) ); see the Mathematica program. - _Pierre-Louis Giscard_, Aug 12 2014
G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = x*(1 + x*A(x/(1 - x))/(1 - x)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 02 2019

A000996.name: Shifts 3 places left under binomial transform.
formula: G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = 1 + x^3 * A(x/(1 - x)) / (1 - x). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 09 2020

A000997.name: From a differential equation.
formula: G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = x*(1 + x^2*A(x/(1 - x))/(1 - x)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 02 2019

A000998.name: From a differential equation.
formula: G.f.: A(x) = Sum(x^(3*k-3)/Product(1-l*x,l = 0 .. k)^3,k = 0 .. infinity). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 05 2008

A000999.name: 5-adic valuation of binomial(2*n,n): largest k such that 5^k divides binomial(2*n, n).

A001000.name: a(n) = least m such that if a/b < c/d where a,b,c,d are integers in [0,n], then a/b < k/m < c/d for some integer k.
formula: For n >= 2, a(n) = (n-[r])(n-[r+1/2])+1, where r = sqrt(4n-7), [x] = greatest integer <= x. - _David W. Wilson_, Aug 30 2007
